CHAPTER 110:  GENERAL LICENSE REQUIREMENTS



Section



   110.01   Business license required



   110.02   Expiration



   110.03   Proration of license fees



   110.04   Revocation of license



   110.05   License application forms



Cross-reference:



   Plumbing license, see §§ 154.15 and 154.35



   Electrical license, see § 155.30



   Garbage collection license, see § 92.40



§ 110.01  BUSINESS LICENSE REQUIRED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to own, operate, or manage any
business, place of amusement, profession, or occupation for which a license
is required, unless a license has been procured from the Clerk-Treasurer,
this license to be issued by the Clerk-Treasurer upon the payment of the
amount of license tax required.



(`81 Code, § 110.01)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 110.02  EXPIRATION.



   All annual licenses or licenses for which an annual fee is charged,
issued by the city to any person under any provision of this code or any
ordinance of the city, unless otherwise provided, shall expire on December 31
of each year.  All other licenses shall be dated as of the date of issuance.



(`81 Code, § 110.02)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 110.03  PRORATION OF LICENSE FEES.



   In the event application is made for any license required by this code
or any other ordinance of the city after August 1 in any year, the fees to be
charged for any yearly license shall be one-half of the amount provided for
the license, unless otherwise provided in this code.



(`81 Code, § 110.03)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 110.04  REVOCATION OF LICENSE.



   (A)   Any person licensed by the city who is guilty of any fraud,
breach, misrepresentation, or imposition, or who violates, neglects, or
refuses to comply with any of the provisions of this code or any other
ordinance of the city relative to licenses, shall be punished as provided for
a violation of this code, and the issuing agency, on proof of a second
violation by any person licensed under this chapter, any other provision of
this code, or any other ordinance of the city relative to licenses, shall
have power to revoke the license issued to the offender.



   (B)   This section shall not be construed to limit or restrict in
any manner whatsoever any other provision of this code relative to revocation
of licenses.



   (C)   The Mayor shall have the authority to revoke the license of
any person issued under the provisions of this code for any violation, upon
conviction, of the laws of the state, the United States, any provision of
this code, or any other ordinance of the city, in connection with the
operation of the place of business or for any other reason that is provided
by law or ordinance.



(`81 Code, § 110.04)  Penalty, see § 10.99



Statutory reference:



   Authority of Mayor to revoke licenses, see I.C. 36-4-5-5



§ 110.05  LICENSE APPLICATION FORMS.



   License application forms under this title shall be approved by the
Board of Public Works and Safety.



(Ord. 08-2611, passed 5-5-08)



CHAPTER 111:  ADVERTISING AND HANDBILLS



Section



   111.01   Definitions



   111.02   Compliance with chapter



   111.03   Distribution of advertising matter



   111.04   Discarding advertising matter on public ways



   111.05   Attachment to trees or structures



   111.06   Attachment to sidewalks or public buildings



   111.07   Defacement of advertisements or notices



   111.08   General prohibition



§ 111.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   ADVERTISING MATTER.  Any written or printed paper, card, circular,
coupon, pamphlet, or folder intended for general distribution, except
newspapers.



   SAMPLE.  Any package, parcel, or item of merchandise intended for
general distribution and for which no charge is made.



(`81 Code, § 111.01) 



§ 111.02  COMPLIANCE WITH CHAPTER.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute any advertising
matter, circular, or sample in the city except as provided in this chapter.



(`81 Code, § 111.02)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 111.03  DISTRIBUTION OF ADVERTISING MATTER.



   (A)   No person shall, within the city, throw, scatter, distribute,
or cause to be thrown, scattered, or distributed, any poster, sign, card,
pamphlet, sample of merchandise, or other advertising device upon any
sidewalk, street, lane, alley, public ground, or other public place, or upon
any private lot or porch, or throw into or upon or attach to any vehicle any
advertising matter or sample.



   (B)   It shall not be unlawful to distribute advertising matter or
samples to private residences, offices, or mercantile establishments if the
material is handed in at the door or securely fastened to prevent it from
being blown or scattered about.



(`81 Code, § 111.03)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 111.04  DISCARDING ADVERTISING MATTER ON PUBLIC WAYS.



   It shall be unlawful for any person, when removing any old poster,
card, or other advertising matter, to leave or deposit it upon any public or
private sidewalk, street, alley, lot, or ground within the city.



(`81 Code, § 111.04)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 111.05  ATTACHMENT TO TREES OR STRUCTURES.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to post, paste, or in any
way attach or affix any bill, notice, announcement, or other advertisement to
any tree located in any alley, street, or other public place in the city, or
upon or to any pole used for telegraph, telephone, electric light, fire
alarm, or any other purpose authorized by the City Council of the city.



   (B)   The provisions of this section shall not apply to the posting
of any notice or order of any court, nor to the posting of any legal notice
required or authorized by law.



(`81 Code, § 111.05)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 111.06  ATTACHMENT TO SIDEWALKS OR PUBLIC BUILDINGS.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to paste, write, paint, place, or
fasten in any manner any poster, sign, card, sample package, or other
advertising matter or device onto any public sidewalk, curb, or pavement or
onto any public building or other public improvement within the city.



(`81 Code, § 111.06)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 111.07  DEFACEMENT OF ADVERTISEMENTS OR NOTICES.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to pull down, deface, or destroy
any written or printed notice, advertisement, or bill posted up at any place
in the city, when the notice, advertisement, or bill has been posted by
permission of the owner or persons having control of the place whereon the
posting is made, and is otherwise lawful.



(`81 Code, § 111.07)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 111.08  GENERAL PROHIBITION



   It shall be unlawful for any person to cry aloud upon the streets or in
the doorways of any place of business along the street, advertising any
commercial business whatever.



(`81 Code, § 111.08)  Penalty, see § 10.99



CHAPTER 112:  AMUSEMENTS AND AMUSEMENT DEVICES



Section



   112.01   Definitions



   112.02   Pool or billiard rooms



Cross-reference:



   Dance hall zoning requirements, see §§ 150.185 and 150.186



§ 112.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   DANCE HALL.  Any structure or place where the public generally, or
groups of persons, are invited to engage in dancing for valuable
consideration, paid either directly or indirectly, or as an incident to the
purchase of merchandise or food.



   DRIVE-IN.  Any business or place of business engaged in the selling at
retail of soft drinks, food, ice cream, or other confections, and providing
facilities for the driving in or parking of automobiles or other vehicles for
the purpose of selling or delivering these goods to the occupants of the
vehicles.



   OPERATOR.  Any person who is the owner, lessee, or occupant of real
estate on which a skating rink, dance hall, or drive-in is conducted or
maintained.



   SKATING RINK.  Any business or place of business where the public
generally, or groups of persons, are invited to engage in skating for
valuable consideration, paid either directly or indirectly, and do so engage.



(`81 Code, § 112.01)



§ 112.02  POOL OR BILLIARD ROOMS.



   Any person owning, keeping, or assisting in keeping any public billiard
hall, public poolroom, or other public place within the city where tables are
used for playing games, shall have pool tables located in the building. 
Persons owning or keeping a public billiard hall, pool room, or other public
place where tables are used for playing games, shall pay a one-time license
fee of $25 to the City Clerk-Treasurer to permit the use of such business.



(`81 Code, § 112.03) (Ord. 2055, passed 3-2-92)  Penalty, see § 10.99



Cross-reference:



   Revocation of pool or billiard room license, see § 110.04



CHAPTER 113:  AUCTIONS



Section



   113.01   Noise to attract attention prohibited



   113.02   Auctions on public streets



   113.03   Auctions conducted from stores



§ 113.01  NOISE TO ATTRACT ATTENTION PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person by outcry, ringing a bell, blowing
a horn, beating a drum or making any other noise, or causing such noise to be
made, to attract the attention of persons to any auction sale in the city.



(`81 Code, § 113.01) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 113.02  AUCTIONS ON PUBLIC STREETS.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or cry for sale at a public
auction any articles of goods, wares, or merchandise on any of the public
streets, alleys, or public grounds of the city.



(`81 Code, § 113.02) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 113.03  AUCTIONS CONDUCTED FROM STORES.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or cry for sale at a public
auction any goods, chattels, wares, or merchandise from any open door or
window in any store, shop, or other building in the city, so as to collect
persons upon any sidewalk or street in the city, whereby the passage of
persons along the sidewalks or streets is hindered or in any manner
obstructed.



(`81 Code, § 113.03) Penalty, see § 10.99

Section

   114.03   Fee



   114.04   Revocation



   114.05   Regulation of food sold from vehicles



   114.06   Exemptions

   114.20   Purpose; definitions

   114.22   Requirements of registration

Cross-reference:



   Bed and breakfast inn zoning requirements, see §§ 150.175 -  150.178



FOOD HANDLERS



§ 114.01  LICENSE REQUIRED FOR SALE OF FOOD FROM VEHICLES.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to use or permit the use of any
vehicle, including wagons, motor vehicles, and vehicles propelled by
manpower, for the sale or offering for sale of any unpackaged, uncartoned, or
unbottled products, merchandise, food, or beverage intended for human
consumption, on any public street or sidewalk in the city, unless a license
for the vehicle is secured and the provisions of this chapter are fully
complied with.



(`81 Code, § 114.01) (Ord. 1308, passed 5-1-62) Penalty, see § 10.99



Cross-reference:



   General license requirements, see Chapter 110



Statutory reference:



   Authority to regulate conduct for the preservation of public health,
safety, and welfare, see I.C. 36-8-2-4



§ 114.02  APPLICATION.



   (A)   Applications for licenses shall be addressed to the Board of
Public Works and Safety and filed at the office of the City Clerk-Treasurer.



   (B)   The applications shall recite the name of the owner of each
vehicle; names of the persons that will operate the vehicle, including the
age and address of the operator; a full description of the vehicle to be used
in the business; and a full description of the unpackaged, uncartoned, or
unbottled products, merchandise, food, or beverage that will be sold or
offered for sale.



(`81 Code, § 114.02) (Ord. 1308, passed 5-1-62) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 114.03  FEE.



   (A)   The annual fee for the licenses shall be $25 for the first
vehicle so licensed, and $5 for each additional vehicle, and shall be issued
for one year beginning on the first day of January of each calendar year.



   (B)   The fees shall be paid to the City Clerk- Treasurer at the
time the application is filed.



(`81 Code, § 114.03) (Ord. 1308, passed 5-1-62) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 114.04  REVOCATION.



   Any license granted pursuant to this chapter may be revoked, without
notice, by the Board of Public Works and Safety because of any violation by
the registrant, or his or her officers, employees or agents, of this section
or § 114.05, or of any other ordinance of the city or of any state or
federal law.



(`81 Code, § 114.04) (Ord. 1308, passed 5-1-62)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 114.05  REGULATION OF FOOD SOLD FROM VEHICLES.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person using a vehicle under the
provisions of this chapter to engage in business without complying with this
code and all other city ordinances, all regulations of the County Department
of Public Health, all regulations of the State Department of Public Health,
and all other recognized food handling regulatory agencies.



   (B)   Whenever a vehicle is used for selling or offering for sale
any products, merchandise, food, or beverages, the vehicle shall be parked
flush with the curb of the street, in compliance with applicable city laws
and state statutes, and sales shall only be made from the side of the vehicle
next to the curb or sidewalk of the street.



   (C)   It is unlawful for any mobile vehicle unit to be used, or the
operator thereof to sell or offer for sale products, merchandise, food, or
beverages by outcry, the ringing of bells, the playing of music, or the
making of any other noise in excess of 115 decibels measured at six inches
from the sound- producing amplifier and mechanism.  Noise shall cease upon
stopping for sales.



   (D)   All mobile vehicles that are to be used in selling or offering
for sale any food or beverage shall be kept in a clean and sanitary
condition, and shall be thoroughly cleaned each day they are so used.



(`81 Code, § 114.05) (Ord. 1308, passed 5-1-62) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 114.06  EXEMPTIONS.



   The Board of Public Works and Safety may exempt special events from the
requirements of this chapter.



(`81 Code, § 114.06)



CAFÉ USE FOR SIDEWALKS



§ 114.20  PURPOSE; DEFINITIONS.



   (A)   It is the purpose of this subchapter to benefit the residents
of the city as a whole by identifying sidewalk café, outdooor dining and
promoting pedestrian traffic in commercial areas, enhancing the
attractiveness of the downtown business zone; and making beverages and food
conveniently available for members of the public, without creating a health
or safety hazard or inconveniencing pedestrians.



   (B)   As used in this subchapter, the following terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this section.



      ABUTTING BUSINESS PROPERTY.  Any real property which is used for
retail business, which abuts (but is not located in) the public sidewalk area.



      CAFÉ ACTIVITY.  The retail sale of non-alcoholic beverages or
food, or the provision of a place for the consumption of beverages or food.



      CAFÉ AREA.  The area used for café activity and shall include
the sidewalk area from the abutting business property extending toward the
curb which provides both adequate seating capacity and effective walkway
width of the public sidewalk area.



      EFFECTIVE WALKWAY WIDTH.  That portion of the sidewalk in the
public sidewalk area that is reasonably available for use by the pedestrian
stream to move unencumbered through the area.



      PUBLIC SIDEWALK AREA.  A sidewalk area located in the public
right-of-way or in an area in which the public has an easement for sidewalk
purposed, or both.



      SEATING CAPACITY.  For consumption of non-alcoholic beverages or
food shall be limited by a 2:1 ratio (two seats per each linear foot of
building frontage).



      SIDEWALK SALES AREA.  The portion of the public sidewalk which
has been registered with the Board of Public Works and Safety for the purpose
of providing a café area.



(`81 Code, § 114.20) (Ord. 99-2333, passed 8-16-99)



§ 114.21  REGISTRATION REQUIRED.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for a person to engage in café activity
on a public sidewalk area without first obtaining a certificate of
registration from the Board of Public Works and Safety.



   (B)   The Board of Public Works and Safety is authorized to approve
a registration of a business to use a sidewalk sales area situated
immediately next to the abutting business property for the sole purpose of
engaging in café activity.



(`81 Code, § 114.21) (Ord. 99-2333, passed 8-16-99)



§ 114.22  REQUIREMENTS OF REGISTRATION.



   (A)   A business which desires to register to use a sidewalk sales
area for café activity shall submit a written request for registration to
the Board of Public Works and Safety.



   (B)   The Board of Public Works and Safety shall approve and issue a
certificate of registration if the subsequent requirements are met:



      (1)   The applicant shall be actively engaged in a retail
business involving the sale of beverages or food in the abutting business
property. The beverages or food sold in the café area must also be sold in
the retail business, and the square footage of the proposed café area must
not exceed the total square footage of the abutting retail business.



      (2)   The public sidewalk area immediately next to the
abutting business property of the registrant shall be at least six feet from
the curb edge.



      (3)   Applicable permits required by the Board of Health shall
have been secured and must be adhered to. Additionally, all promulgated rules
of the Indiana Fire Prevention and Building Safety Commission shall be
adhered to.



      (4)   Proposed equipment necessary to conduct café activity
(for example, tables, chairs, carts, and the like) will be temporary in
nature so they can easily be removed from the public sidewalk area during
non-business hours and/or off-season time periods.



      (5)   The applicant will provide a document and proof of
insurance liability on an annual basis which agrees to indemnify and hold
harmless the city for losses or expenses arising out of the operation of a
café area on a public sidewalk.



      (6)   An illustration for placement of equipment in café area
will be submitted with the request for registration.



(`81 Code, § 114.22) (Ord. 99-2333, passed 8-16-99)



§ 114.23  RESTRICTIONS ON OPERATION.



   (A)   Beverages or food sold in the café area of a public sidewalk
shall be provided only for consumption in the sidewalk sales area, or in the
abutting business property.



   (B)   Provision shall be made to assure the sidewalk will not be
littered, including placement of adequate trash receptacles.



   (C)   Sales of beverages or food may not be made to a person in or
on any motorized vehicle.



   (D)   No equipment shall be located in any part of the street,
median or alley way which would in any way obstruct the flow of, or impede
the vision of, vehicular traffic.



   (E)   Pedestrians shall not be exposed to any undue safety or health
hazard nor shall a public nuisance be created.



(`81 Code, § 114.23) (Ord. 99-2333, passed 8-16-99)



§ 114.24  REGISTRATION TERM, ENFORCEMENT AND RENEWAL.



   (A)   A certificate of registration under this subchapter shall be
valid for a period of one year from the date of issuance.



   (B)   Inspections may be conducted at the discretion of the Board of
Public Works and Safety, or by its appointee or agent. Violations of any
restrictions of operation (as listed in § 114.23) may lead to the Board
suspending the registration pending consideration of further action.



   (C)   A certificate of registration may be revoked by the Board of
Public Works and Safety if documented violations deem necessary.



   (D)   Renewal for a certificate of registration for café activity
shall be granted upon written request within 30 days of expiration providing
no violations have occurred during the term of existing registration.



   (E)   Renewal, or reconsideration for a revoked certificate of
registration for café activity will be considered, then granted or denied at
the discretion of the Board of Public Works and Safety.



(`81 Code, § 114.24) (Ord. 99-2333, passed 8-16-99)



CHAPTER 115:  PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS, AND ITINERANT MERCHANTS

   115.17   Storage of items



   115.18   Signage



   115.19   Sanitation duties



 



   115.99   Penalty



§ 115.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   PEDDLER.  Any person traveling by foot, wagon, automotive vehicle, or
any other type of conveyance from place to place, from house to house, or
from street to street carrying, conveying, or transporting goods, wares,
merchandise, food products, offering and exposing them for sale, or making
sales and delivering articles to purchasers, or who, without traveling from
place to place, shall sell or offer the same for sale from a wagon,
automotive vehicle, railroad car, or other vehicle or conveyance. However,
one who solicits orders and as a separate transaction makes deliveries to
purchasers as a part of a scheme or design to evade the provisions of this
chapter shall be deemed a peddler subject to the provisions of this
chapter.  This definition, however, shall not be construed to include
commercial travelers or salespersons calling exclusively upon businesses,
professional persons, schools, or public institutions for the purpose of
taking orders or selling books, equipment, supplies, or services used
professionally thereby, and shall not be construed to include persons selling
exclusively products grown by these persons.  The word PEDDLER shall include
the words hawker and huckster.



   SOLICITOR.  Any person traveling from place to place, from house to
house, or from street to street within the city, or contacting persons by
telephone within the city, for the purpose of taking orders for the sale of
goods, wares, merchandise, magazines, books, or personal property of any
nature whatsoever for a future delivery, or for services to be furnished or
performed in the future, regardless of whether the person has, carries, or
exposes for sale a sample of the subject of the sale or whether he or she is
collecting  advance payments on the sales or who solicits  monies 
door-to-door for non-profit or not- for-profit organizations.  This 
definition, however, shall not include commercial travelers or salesmen
calling exclusively upon businesses, professional persons, schools, or public
institutions for the purpose of taking orders or selling books, equipment,
supplies, or services used professionally thereby.  The word SOLICITOR shall
include the word canvasser.



   TENT SALES.  The temporary outside display or sale of goods or
merchandise not in or from an enclosed permanent building, subject to the
provisions of the zoning code.  TENT SALES may not be conducted for a period
of more than three days at any approved location in any calendar year.  Once
a merchant has conducted the permitted TENT SALE, that merchant or his or her
agents may not conduct another TENT SALE within the current calendar year
from any location within the jurisdictional areas of the city.



   TRANSIENT MERCHANT.  Any person, whether as owner, agent, consignee,
or employee, who engages in a temporary business of selling and delivering
goods, wares, and merchandise within the city, and who, in furtherance of
this purpose, hires, leases, uses, or occupies any building, structure, motor
vehicle, tent, railroad boxcar, boat, public room in hotels, motels, lodging
houses, apartments, shops, or any street, alley, or other place within the
city, for the exhibition and sale of the goods, wares, and merchandise,
either privately or at public auction.  However, this definition shall not
be construed to include any person who, while occupying temporary location,
does not sell from stock, but exhibits samples only for the purpose of
securing orders for future delivery only, and this definition shall not be
construed to include any person who is a commercial traveler or salesperson
calling exclusively upon businesses, professional persons, schools, or public
institutions for the purposes of taking orders or selling books, equipment,
supplies, or services used professionally thereby, and further shall not be
construed to include any person selling exclusively products grown by that
person.  A person shall be a transient merchant even though he or she
temporarily associates with a local dealer, trader, merchant, or auctioneer,
or conducts the transient business in connection with, as a part of, or in
the name of any local dealer, trader, merchant, or auctioneer.  The term
TRANSIENT MERCHANT shall include the terms itinerant merchant and itinerant
vendor.



(`81 Code, § 115.01)  (Ord. 2035, passed 10-7-91; Am. Ord. 01-2409, passed
10-1-01; Am. Ord. 04-2496, passed 4-19-04)



§ 115.02  ORDERS FOR FUTURE DELIVERIES.



   All orders taken by persons required to have licenses under this
chapter shall be in writing in duplicate and shall clearly and distinctly
state the total consideration to be paid by the purchaser. One copy of the
order shall be given to the purchaser at the time of taking it.  In
addition, any representation as to charitable use of the money paid by the
customer should be clearly stated in precise amounts or percentages in the
written order.



(`81 Code, § 115.02) (Ord. 01-2409, passed 10-1-01) 



§ 115.03  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for a transient merchant, peddler, or
solicitor to engage in their respective businesses within the city without
obtaining a license in compliance with the provisions of this chapter.  The
obtaining of a license by an employer or principal shall in no way relieve
any employee or agent of that employer or principal of his or her legal
obligation to obtain a license, if his or her activity falls within the
definition set out in § 115.01.



   (B)   Licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall
contain the information and be in the form prescribed by the Board of Public
Works and Safety.



   (C)   It shall be unlawful for a transient merchant, peddler or
solicitor to engage in his or her respective business within the city after
7:00 p.m.  The license to be issued shall show on its face that there shall
be no door-to-door solicitations after 7:00 p.m.



(`81 Code, § 115.03) (Ord. 2035, passed 10-7-91; Am. Ord. 01-2409, passed
10-1-01)  Penalty, see § 115.99



Cross-reference:



   General license requirements, see Chapter 110



Statutory reference:



   Authority to license transient merchants, see I.C. 25-37-1-11



§ 115.04  APPLICATION.



   (A)   Applicants for any license under this chapter, whether a
natural person, firm, or corporation, except for not-for-profit organizations
provided in division (M), shall file a written sworn application signed by
the applicant, if an individual, by all partners if a partnership, and by the
president if a corporation, with the Clerk-Treasurer showing the following
information.



   (B)   The name and description of the applicant and, if a firm, the
names of the persons having the management or supervision of the
applicant’s business during the time that it is proposed that it will be
carried on in the city.



   (C)   The full permanent address and full local address of the
applicant.



   (D)   A brief description of the nature of the business and the
goods to be sold, whether the goods are proposed to be sold from stock in
possession, or from stock in possession and by sample; to be sold at auction,
direct sale, or by direct sale and by taking orders for future delivery;
where the goods or property proposed to be sold are manufactured or produced;
and where the goods are located at the time the application is filed.



   (E)   If the applicant is employed or acting as an agent, the name
and address of the employer or principal, together with credentials
establishing the exact relationship.



   (F)   The place within the city where the applicant proposes to
carry on his or her business and the length of time during which the
applicant proposes that the business shall be conducted.



   (G)   If one or more vehicles are to be used, a description of them,
together with license numbers or other means of identification.



   (H)   A photograph  of  the  applicant,  or  if  a 
corporation, a photograph of the person to have the management or supervision
of the applicant’s business in the city, taken within 60 days immediately
prior to the date of the filing of the application, the picture to be
approximately two inches by two inches, showing the head and shoulders of the
applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner.



   (I)   The places, other than the permanent place of business of the
applicant, where the applicant within the six months next preceding the date
of his or her application conducted such a business, stating the nature
thereof and giving the post office and street address of any building or
office in which the business was conducted.



   (J)   A criminal background check in a form as provided by the state
police.



   (K)   A statement of the nature and character of any advertising
done or proposed to be done in order to attract customers.



   (L)   Any other reasonable information as to the identity or
character of the applicant; or his or her agents or employees or the method
or plan of doing business that the Board of Public Works and Safety may deem
proper to fulfill the purpose of this chapter in the protection of the public
good and welfare.



   (M)   A not-for-profit organization shall only be required to
provide a copy of their determination letter from the Internal Revenue
Service, along with the following:



      (1)   The name and description of the applicant and, if a
firm, the names of the persons having the management or supervision of the
applicant’s business during the time it is proposed that it will be carried
on in the city.



      (2)   The full permanent address and full local address of the
applicant.



(`81 Code, § 115.04) (Ord. 01-2409, passed 10-1-01) 



§ 115.05  BOND.



   (A)   Before any license as provided for by this chapter shall be
issued, a bond shall be filed by the applicant with the Clerk-Treasurer,
running to the city in the sum of $1,000, conditioned that the applicant and
his or her agents and employees shall comply fully with all the provisions of
this code, other ordinances of the city, and the statutes of the state
regulating and concerning the sale of goods, wares, and merchandise and the
business of a transient merchant, peddler, or solicitor, whichever shall be
applicable, and will pay all judgments rendered against the applicant or his
or her agents or employees for any violation of them, together with all
judgments and costs that may be recovered by any person for damage growing
out of any misrepresentation or deceptions were made or practiced at the time
of making the sale or through advertisement of any character whatsoever
printed or circulated with reference to the goods, wares, and merchandise
sold or any part thereof, or services rendered or to be rendered.



   (B)   Separate bonds need not be executed by each employee or agent,
but one bond may cover all of the employees of one employer or all of the
agents of one principal.



   (C)   The bond shall be executed by the applicant or his or her
employer or principal and two sureties upon which service of process may be
made in the state, and shall be approved by the City Attorney, both as to
form and as to the responsibility of the sureties.



   (D)   Action on the bond may be brought in the name of the city to
the use or benefit of the aggrieved person.



(`81 Code, § 115.05) (Ord. 01-2409, passed 10-1-01) 



§ 115.06  STATEMENT AS TO SERVICE OF PROCESS.



   (A)   Before any license provided for in this chapter shall be
issued, the applicant shall file with the Clerk-Treasurer an instrument
nominating and appointing the sureties as provided for in § 115.05 as his or
her true and lawful agents with power and authority to acknowledge service of
process for and on behalf of the applicant in respect to any and all matters
connected with or arising out of the business transacted under the license
and in regard to the bond given as required by § 115.05, or for the
performance of the conditions of the bond or for any breach thereof.



   (B)   The instrument shall also contain recitals to the effect that
the applicant for the license consents and agrees that service of any notice
or process may be made upon these agents, and when so made shall be taken and
held to be as valid as if personally served upon the person applying for the
license and waiving all claim or right of error by reason of the
acknowledgment of service or manner of service.



(`81 Code, § 115.06) (Ord. 01-2409, passed 10-1-01)



§ 115.07  INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT.



   (A)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall inform the Chief of Police of the
receipt of any application for a license under the provisions of this
chapter, and the Chief of Police shall, within seven days thereafter, cause
an investigation of the person’s business responsibility and moral
character to be made as he or she deems necessary for the protection of the
public good and welfare.



   (B)   If, as a result of the investigation, the applicant’s
character and business responsibility are found to be such as to endanger or
be detrimental to the public and its good and welfare, the license shall be
denied.



   (C)   If, as a result of the investigation, the character and
business reputation of the person applying appear to be such that the
carrying on of the business will not be detrimental to the public good and
welfare and the welfare and good of the public will not be endangered by the
granting of the license, the Chief of Police shall so inform the
Clerk-Treasurer and, upon the applicant’s complying with all other
provisions of this chapter in regard thereto, a license shall be issued by
the Clerk-Treasurer to the applicant.



(`81 Code, § 115.07) (Ord. 01-2409, passed 10-1-01) 



§ 115.08  RIGHT TO APPEAL.



   Any person aggrieved by the decision of the Chief of Police in regard
to the denial of a license as provided for in § 115.07 shall have the right
to appeal to the Board of Public Works and Safety. Appeal shall be taken by
filing with the Board, within 14 days after notice of the decision by the
Chief of Police has been mailed to the person’s last known address, a
written statement setting forth the grounds for the appeal.  The Board shall
set the time and place for a hearing on the appeal and notice of the hearing
shall be given to the person.  The order of the Board on the appeal shall be
final.



(`81 Code, § 115.08) (Ord. 01-2409, passed 10-1-01) 



§ 115.09  USE OF PUBLIC PROPERTY.



   Before any license as herein provided shall be issued for engaging in
business as a peddler, solicitor, or transient merchant, as defined in §
115.01, upon public property, the applicant must obtain permission from the
Board of Public Works and Safety for the use of that property. The Board of
Public Works and Safety shall require the applicant to provide proof of
bodily injury and property damage liability insurance in an amount
satisfactory to the Board.



(Ord. 01-2409, passed 10-1-01)



§ 115.10  LICENSE TERM AND FEE.



   The term for such a license as herein provided shall be 60 days from
the date of issuance, and the fee for such license shall be $100. A
not-for-profit organization shall not be required to pay a fee if the
organization has complied with the requirements of § 115.04 as set forth
herein.  The license issued to each person under this chapter shall, at all
times, be displayed in a prominent place in the particular place of business
or office.



(Ord. 01-2409, passed 10-1-01; Am. Ord. 04-2496, passed 4-19-04)  Penalty,
see § 115.99



§ 115.11  EXPIRATION OF LICENSE.



   All licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall expire
60 days after the date of issuance thereof unless a prior date is fixed
therein.



(`81 Code, § 115.11)  (Ord. 01-2409, passed 10-1-01) Penalty, see § 115.99



§ 115.12  TRANSFERENCE OF LICENSE.



   All licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be
non-transferable.



(Ord. 01-2409, passed 10-1-01) Penalty, see § 115.99



§ 115.13  DUTY OF POLICE TO ENFORCE.



   It shall be the duty of the police officers of the city to examine all
places of business and persons in their respective territories subject to the
provisions of this subchapter, to determine if this subchapter has been
complied with and to enforce the provisions of this subchapter against any
person found to be violating the same.



(Ord. 01-2409, passed 10-1-01)



§ 115.14  RECORDS OF LICENSES TO BE KEPT.



   The Clerk-Treasurer shall deposit the records described herein of
license, together with a license number, with the Chief of Police; the Chief
of Police shall report to the Clerk-Treasurer any complaints against any
persons licensed under the provisions of this chapter and any conviction for
violation of this chapter; the Clerk-Treasurer shall keep a record of all
licenses and of those complaints and violations.



(Ord. 01-2409, passed 10-1-01)



§ 115.15  SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION.



   (A)   The permits and licenses issued pursuant to this chapter may
be revoked by the Board of Public Works and Safety after notice and hearing,
for any of the following causes:



      (1)   Any fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement
contained in the application for the license.



      (2)   Any fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement made in
connection with the selling of goods, wares or merchandise.



      (3)   Any violation of this chapter.



      (4)   Conviction of the licensee of any felony or of a
misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; or



      (5)   Conducting the business licensed under this chapter in
an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace
or to constitute a menace to the health, safety, or general welfare of the
public.



   (B)   Notice of hearing of revocation of a license shall be given in
writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time
and place of the hearing.  The notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to
the licensee at his or her last known address, at least five days prior to
the date set for the hearing.



(`81 Code, § 115.12)  (Ord. 01-2409, passed 10-1-01) Penalty, see § 115.99



§ 115.16  LICENSING DURING BEARS OF BLUE RIVER FESTIVAL.



   (A)   The Bears of Blue River Festival shall have the right and
authority to license any peddlers or transient merchants during the
officially-designated period of the annual Bears of Blue River Festival.



   (B)   This definition of peddlers and transient merchants shall
continue as set forth in § 115.01.



   (C)   The Board of Public Works and Safety shall retain full
authority to license any peddlers or transient merchants as set forth in this
chapter, however, this authority shall be shared with the Bears of Blue River
Festival Committee during that week.



   (D)   The Bears of Blue River Festival Committee shall be allowed to
charge fees for the issuance of licenses to these peddlers or transient
merchants.  Sums collected for these licenses shall be deemed to be the
property of the Bears of Blue River Festival Committee.



   (E)   No peddler or transient merchant shall be allowed to engage in
his or her business during the Bears of Blue River Festival without being
licensed by either the Bears of Blue River Festival Committee or the Board of
Public Works and Safety. 



(`81 Code, § 115.13)  (Ord. 1997, passed 7-2-90; Am. Ord. 01-2409, passed
10-1-01) Penalty, see § 115.99



§ 115.17  STORAGE OF ITEMS.



   The overnight storage of inventory or other sales items is prohibited
unless said items are completely secured and obscured from public view.



(Ord. 04-2496, passed 4-19-04)  Penalty, see § 115.99



§ 115.18  SIGNAGE.



   There shall be no other use of signage except those that are
permanently affixed to any vehicle or structure in conjunction with any
temporary sales within the city's jurisdictional areas.  Further, there
shall be no use of canopies, umbrellas or other appurtenances except as may
be necessary in the event of inclement weather.



(Ord. 04-2496, passed 4-19-04)  Penalty, see § 115.99



§ 115.19  SANITATION DUTIES.



   The vendor shall be responsible for the collection and disposal of all
trash and debris that may accumulate within 100 feet of any approved sale
location.  All debris shall be removed before the conclusion of the
permitted sale event.



(Ord. 04-2496, passed 4-19-04)  Penalty, see § 115.99



§ 115.99  PENALTY.



   Whoever violates the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less
than $10 nor more than $2,500.  Each day’s continued violation shall
constitute a separate offense.



(Ord. 01-2409, passed 10-1-01)



CHAPTER 116:  PEST CONTROL BUSINESSES



Section




General Provisions




   116.01   Definitions



   116.02   Applicability of chapter



   116.03   Compliance with chapter



   116.04   Use of toxic insecticides



   116.05   Fumigation procedure




License Requirements




   116.10   License required



   116.11   Types of licenses



   116.12   Licensee is partnership or corporation



   116.13   Fees



   116.14   Examination of applicants



   116.15   Refusal or revocation



   116.16   Bond or insurance policy required



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 116.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   FUMIGANT.  Any substance which by itself or in combination with any
other substance emits or liberates, or is made to emit or liberate, a gas,
fume, or vapor used for the destruction or control of insects, vermin,
rodents, or other pests.



   FUMIGATION.  The use of fumigants as defined under this section.



   INSECTICIDE.  Any substance, powder or liquid, not a fumigant, used
for destruction, repelling, or controlling of insects, vermin, rodents, or
other pests.



   PEST CONTROL.  Work designed to eliminate or control insects, vermin,
rodents, or other pests by the use of insecticide liquid or powder, as
distinguished from fumigants.



(`81 Code, § 116.01) 



§ 116.02  APPLICABILITY OF CHAPTER.



   (A)   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to a person
using an insecticide in his own residence or in his own place of business,
provided no insecticide shall be used where food is stored, prepared, held,
or kept for sale.



   (B)   This section shall not apply to agricultural or horticultural
pest control or fumigation, except in cases where an insecticide or fumigant
is used on agricultural or horticultural products at a place where they are
grown.



   (C)   This section shall not apply to any person engaged as an owner
or employee in a business which requires the use of fumigants in connection
with its own products, wares, goods, or merchandise, or the goods, wares, and
merchandise of others stored upon the premises; however, any person who
conducts fumigation or pest control work under these circumstances shall be
approved as a qualified operator by the Board of Health.



(`81 Code, § 116.02)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 116.03  COMPLIANCE WITH CHAPTER.



   No person shall use insecticides or fumigants or engage in pest control
or fumigation work within the city unless the work is done in accordance with
the provisions of this chapter, the terms of the license issued therefor, and
the regulations of the Board of Health.



(`81 Code, § 116.03)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 116.04  USE OF TOXIC INSECTICIDES.



   It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to use any
insecticide which is deemed by the Board of Health of the city to be highly
toxic or poisonous.



(`81 Code, § 116.04)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 116.05  FUMIGATION PROCEDURE.



   (A)   Masks.  All masks used in connection with fumigation shall be
of the type approved by the United States Bureau of Mines.



   (B)   Notification of the Police and Fire Departments and the Board
of Health.  Every holder of a fumigation or pest control license shall
notify the Police Department, Fire Department, and Board of Health before
commencing any fumigation.



   (C)   Service of warning on occupants of building. Written or
printed notice or warning shall be served on all occupants of the building in
which the fumigation or pest control work is to be done.



   (D)   Warning signs.  Prior to fumigation, suitable warning signs
shall be posted on all doors or entrances to the premises to be fumigated,
bearing the following notice:  “Danger - Keep Out.  This place is being
fumigated with a deadly gas.  No one is allowed to enter until after
operator in charge has aired out thoroughly.”  Such signs shall be printed
in red ink and the words “DANGER - KEEP OUT” shall be in letters at least
two inches in height.



   (E)   Entering of rooms during fumigation.  Only fumigation
operators shall be allowed to enter the rooms to be fumigated during the
placing of the fumigants.  No one shall be allowed to enter the premises
upon which work is being performed until the work has been completed and the
premises have been thoroughly aired and made safe for occupancy.



   (F)   Removal and disposal of containers, residues, and the like.
All fumigant containers, residues, and materials shall be removed from the
premises and properly disposed of in accordance with the recommendations and
instructions of the manufacturers.



(`81 Code, § 116.05)  Penalty, see § 10.99



LICENSE REQUIREMENTS



§ 116.10  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   No person shall use insecticides or fumigants or engage in pest control
or fumigation work within the city unless that person is the holder of a
license issued by the Board of Health.



(`81 Code, § 116.10)  Penalty, see § 10.99



Cross-reference:



   General license requirements, see Chapter 110



§ 116.11  TYPES OF LICENSES.



   (A)   Licenses shall be issued by the Board of Health under this
chapter covering the following classifications.



      (1)   Fumigation license for the conduct of the business of
fumigation and pest control.



      (2)   Pest control license for the conduct of the business of
pest control only.



      (3)   Owner-operator license for the individual owner of
either a fumigation or pest control business, who is also an operator.



      (4)   Employee-operator license for the employees of either a
fumigation or pest control business.



   (B)   The holder of either an owner-operator or employee-operator
license for fumigation may also engage in pest control work.  The holder of
a pest control license may engage only in pest control work.  The holder of
an employee-operator license may engage in fumigation or pest control work
only in the course of employment on behalf of the holder of an owner-operator
license.



(`81 Code, § 116.11)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 116.12  LICENSEE IS PARTNERSHIP OR CORPORATION.



   (A)   If the applicant for a fumigation license or pest control
license is a partnership, at least one member thereof shall be the holder of
an owner- operator license of the same class.



   (B)   If the applicant for a fumigation license or a pest control
license is a corporation, at least one officer thereof shall be the holder of
an owner- operator license of the same class.



(`81 Code, § 116.12)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 116.13  FEES.



   Applicants for the issuance of a license under the provisions of this
chapter shall be required to pay the following amounts as annual fees for the
licenses.



   (A)   Fumigation license, $10 per year.



   (B)   Pest control license, $25 per year.



   (C)   Owner-operator license, $2 per year.



   (D)   Employee-operator license, $2 per year.



(`81 Code, § 116.13)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 116.14  EXAMINATION OF APPLICANTS.



   Before any license shall be issued under the provisions of this
chapter, all applicants for an owner- operator license or for an
employee-operator license shall be required to submit to and to pass an
examination given by the Board of Health covering the knowledge, ability, and
experience of the applicant to do the particular work covered by the license
for which application is made.



(`81 Code, § 116.14)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 116.15  REFUSAL OR REVOCATION.



   Licenses under this chapter may be refused or revoked by the Board of
Health of the city after proper hearing, in the event the Board determines
that such action is necessary for the protection of public health and safety.



(`81 Code, § 116.15)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 116.16  BOND OR INSURANCE POLICY REQUIRED.



   (A)   Every person making application for the issuance of a
fumigation or pest control license shall annually file with the
Clerk-Treasurer a good and sufficient bond or policy of insurance running to
the city in the penal sum of not less that $5,000.



   (B)   The bond or policy shall be conditioned to indemnify and to
save and keep harmless the city from any and all costs or damages which may
be sustained by the city, or expense of any kind whatsoever, to which it may
be put or which may accrue against the city by reason of the granting or
issuance of any of the licenses provided under this chapter.



   (C)   The bond or policy shall also be conditioned to indemnify any
and all persons who may suffer injury or damages to property by reason of
improper, negligent, or careless performance of fumigation or pest control
work.



(`81 Code, § 116.16)  Penalty, see § 10.99



CHAPTER 117:  SECONDHAND DEALERS, JUNK DEALERS, AND PAWNBROKERS



Section




Secondhand Dealers




   117.01   Definition



   117.02   Records to be kept



   117.03   Right of inspection by police



   117.04   Purchases, sales by minors



   117.05   Purchases from thieves




Junk Dealers




   117.10   Definitions



   117.11   License required



   117.12   Application



   117.13   Annual fee



   117.14   Transferability



   117.15   Records to be kept



   117.16   Right of inspection by police



   117.17   Dealing with minors



   117.18   Purchases from thieves



   117.19   Fence required



   117.20   Zoning requirements




Pawnbrokers
