   117.99   Penalty



SECONDHAND DEALERS



§ 117.01  DEFINITION.



   For the purpose of this chapter the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   DEALER IN SECONDHAND GOODS.  Any person who keeps a place of business
for the purchase or sale of secondhand clothing, secondhand furniture, or
secondhand goods, wares, or merchandise of any kind.



(`81 Code, § 117.01)



§ 117.02  RECORDS TO BE KEPT.



   (A)   Record books. Every secondhand dealer shall keep a book in
which shall be fairly and plainly written, in ink and in the English
language, at the time of the purchase or receipt of any article of secondhand
merchandise, an accurate account and description of the article purchased or
received; the name, age, residence and brief description of the person
selling or delivering the article; the price paid therefor; and the date and
hour of the transaction.  All entries shall be made at the time of the
purchase or delivery.  No entry in the book shall be erased, obliterated, or
defaced.



   (B)   Card record for police. In addition to the record book
required by this chapter, all licensees under this chapter shall, at the time
of purchase or receipt of any article of secondhand merchandise, fill out a
three-inch by five-inch card for each article. Each card shall contain the
information required to be kept by licensees under this chapter, and the
right thumbprint of the person selling the article; if the right thumb is
missing, any of the person’s fingerprints may be used. The thumbprint shall
be made in the manner approved by the Police Department and shall not be
blurred or obliterated. The licensees shall mail these cards to the Police
Department no later than the next business day after the item of personal
property is received.



   (C)   List of serialized articles. In addition to the above records,
every licensee under this chapter shall provide a list of serialized articles
that have been acquired by transfers from any location other than the city to
the Police Department no later than the next business day after the articles
are received.



(`81 Code, § 117.02)  (Am. Ord. 09-2640, passed 11-16-09)  Penalty, see §
117.99



§ 117.03  RIGHT OF INSPECTION BY POLICE.



   The book required to be kept by this chapter, as well as every article
of secondhand merchandise purchased or received, shall at all reasonable
times be open to inspection by any member of the police force.



(`81 Code, § 117.03)  Penalty, see § 117.99



Statutory reference:



   Authority of police force to inspect, see I.C. 36-8-3-10



§ 117.04  PURCHASES, SALES BY MINORS.



   (A)   No secondhand dealer shall receive or purchase any property
whatever from a minor at any time.



   (B)   No minor shall sell or offer for sale to any secondhand dealer
any property whatever at any time.



(`81 Code, § 117.04)  Penalty, see § 117.99



§ 117.05  PURCHASES FROM THIEVES.



   No secondhand dealer shall receive or purchase any property whatever at
any time from any intoxicated person, nor from any person known to him or her
to be a thief or to have been convicted of burglary or larceny.



(`81 Code, § 117.05)  Penalty, see § 117.99



JUNK DEALERS



§ 117.10  DEFINITIONS.



   For purposes of this chapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   JUNK DEALERS. Persons engaged in buying and selling old iron, old
copper, old brass, old rubber, old bottles, old machinery, old implements, or
old automobiles, for the purpose of separating the parts thereof and selling
those parts as used parts.



   JUNK SHOPS or JUNK YARDS.  Junk dealers places of business, if within
the enclosed walls of a building, shall be termed JUNK SHOPS; and if these
places of business are not within the enclosed walls of a building they shall
be termed JUNK YARDS.



(`81 Code, § 117.10)



§ 117.11  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a junk
dealer or  to own or manage  any junk shop or junk yard in the city without
procuring from the Clerk-Treasurer a license therefor as provided in this
subchapter.



(`81 Code, § 117.11)  Penalty, see § 117.99



Cross-reference:



   General license requirements, see Chapter 110



§ 117.12  APPLICATION.



   Any person desiring to engage in the business of a junk dealer in the
city, before entering upon the business, shall file with the Clerk-Treasurer
his or her written application duly verified, in which the applicant shall
give his or her name, age, and place of residence for the past 12 months,
together with a specific description of his or her proposed place of
business.  He or she shall also file with the application, the certificate
of at least five reputable freeholders of the city as to his or her good
moral character.



(`81 Code, § 117.12)  (Am. Ord. 08-2610, passed 5-5-08)  Penalty, see §
117.99



§ 117.13  ANNUAL FEE.



   Every person receiving a license as a junk dealer in the city shall pay
to the Clerk-Treasurer at the time of the issuing of the license a fee of
$200, which shall entitle the person to conduct the business for the term of
one year only.  The license may be renewed from year to year by the payment
of the further fee of $200 at the beginning of each year for which the
renewal may be issued.



(`81 Code, § 117.13)  (Am. Ord. 09-2640, passed 11-16-09)  Penalty, see §
117.99



§ 117.14  TRANSFERABILITY.



   Only one junk yard or shop may be owned or operated under one license,
but the license may be transferred by the holder to any other person, upon
the filing of a proper application therefor with the Clerk-Treasurer
accompanied by a transfer fee of $1.



(`81 Code, § 117.14)  Penalty, see § 117.99



§ 117.15  RECORDS TO BE KEPT.



   (A)   Record books. Every junk dealer shall keep a book in which
shall be fairly and plainly written, in ink and in the English language, at
the time of the purchase or receipt of any article of junk, an accurate
account and description of the article purchased or received; the name, age,
residence, and brief description of the person selling or delivering the
article; the price paid therefor; and the date and hour of the transaction. 
All entries shall be made at the time of the purchase or delivery.  No entry
in the book shall be erased, obliterated, or defaced.



   (B)   Card record for police. In addition to the record book
required by this chapter, all licensees under this chapter shall, at the time
of purchase or receipt of any article of junk, fill out a three-inch by
five-inch card for each article. Each card shall contain the information
required to be kept by licensees under this chapter, and the right thumbprint
of the person selling the article; if the right thumb is missing, any of the
person’s fingerprints may be used. The thumbprint shall be made in the
manner approved by the Police Department and shall not be blurred or
obliterated. The licensees shall mail these cards to the Police Department no
later than the next business day after the item of personal property is
received.



   (C)   List of serialized articles. In addition to the above records,
every licensee under this chapter shall provide a list of serialized articles
that have been acquired by transfers from any location other than the city to
the Police Department no later than the next business day after the articles
are received.



(`81 Code, § 117.15)  (Am. Ord. 09-2640, passed 11-16-09)  Penalty, see §
117.99



§ 117.16  RIGHT OF INSPECTION BY POLICE.



   The book required to be kept by § 117.15, as well as every article of
junk purchased or received, shall at all reasonable times be open to
inspection by any member of the police force.



(`81 Code, § 117.16)  Penalty, see § 117.99



Statutory reference:



   Police supervision over junk yard keepers, see I.C. 36-8-3-10



§ 117.17  DEALING WITH MINORS.



   It shall be unlawful for any junk dealer or the owner or manager of any
junk shop or junk yard in the city to purchase or receive any article of junk
from any minor without first having obtained the written consent of the
parent or guardian for the sale or transfer. If the minor has neither parent
nor guardian, then the junk dealer shall require the written statement of
some responsible person that the article, machinery, implement, or old
automobile is the property of the minor and is not stolen property.



(`81 Code, § 117.17)  Penalty, see § 117.99



§ 117.18  PURCHASES FROM THIEVES.



   No junk dealer shall receive or purchase any property whatever at any
time from any intoxicated person, nor from any person known to him or her to
be a thief or to have been convicted of burglary or larceny.



(`81 Code, § 117.18)  Penalty, see § 117.99



§ 117.19  FENCE REQUIRED.



   All junk yard located inside the city limits must be completely
surrounded with a solid fence so that the view of the business inside is
completely blocked from normal view and trash can not blow out of the junk
yard.  The fence cannot be any higher than eight feet tall or any lower than
six feet tall.  No junk is permitted to set on the outside of the fence. 
The fence can be made of wood or metal and must be properly maintained,
including painting.



(`81 Code, § 117.19)  (Ord. 2057, passed 3-16-92)  Penalty, see § 117.99



§ 117.20  ZONING REQUIREMENTS.



   (A)   Junk yards shall be allowed only in M-2 zoning districts.



   (B)   Junk yards shall be permitted as special exceptions only in
the above stated zoning district.



   (C)   In addition to all other considerations that the Board of
Zoning Appeals must concern themselves with respect to any special
exceptions, the Board of Zoning Appeals shall further consider the possible
pollution associated with junk yards and its effect on surrounding property
owners in determining whether such a permit should be granted.



(`81 Code, § 117.20)  (Ord. 2057, passed 3-16-92; Am. Ord. 93-2124, passed
10-4-93)  Penalty, see § 117.99



PAWNBROKERS



§ 117.30  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   PAWNBROKER. Any person, partnership, association, or corporation who
lends money on the deposit or pledge of personal property, or who deals in
the purchase of personal property on the condition of selling the property
back again at a stipulated price, other than choses in action, securities, or
printed evidence of indebtedness.



   PERSON. An individual, a firm, an association, a limited liability
company, a partnership, a joint stock association, a trust, or a corporation
or any other entity capable of suing or being sued.



   PLEDGE. Personal property deposited with a pawnbroker as security for a
loan.



   PLEDGER. The person who delivers personal property into the possession
of a pawnbroker as security for a loan unless such person discloses that the
person is or was acting for another; and in such event PLEDGER means the
disclosed principal.



(Ord. 09-2640, passed 11-16-09)



§ 117.31  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of
pawnbroker without first obtaining a license from the Clerk-Treasurer. In
order to sell secondhand goods, it is not required that a pawnbroker also
obtain a license to be a dealer in secondhand goods for the pawnbroker’s
licensed business location.



(Ord. 09-2640, passed 11-16-09)



Statutory reference:



   Authority to regulate businesses and professions, see I.C. 36-8-2-10



§ 117.32  APPLICATION.



   All applicants shall, as a condition for the granting of a license and
on a portion of the application provided by the Clerk-Treasurer, agree that
in the event the applicant as licensee receives personal property of any kind
which is stolen, he or she claims no right, title or interest in or to the
personal property, and that upon request by any law enforcement officer
having jurisdiction over the location of his or her place of business, he or
she will voluntarily surrender the personal property to the possession of
that law enforcement agency when given receipt for the same.



(Ord. 09-2640, passed 11-16-09)



§ 117.33  ANNUAL FEE.



   Every person receiving a license as a pawnbroker in the city shall pay
to the Clerk-Treasurer at the time of the issuing of the license a fee of
$200 for each place of business of the licensee, which shall entitle the
person to conduct the business for the term of one year only. The license may
be renewed from year to year by the payment of the further fee of $200 at the
beginning of each year for which the renewal may be issued.



(Ord. 09-2640, passed 11-16-09)



§ 117.34  UNLAWFUL PURCHASES.



   It shall be unlawful for any licensee under this chapter to receive any
articles in the course of his or her business from any person who is in an
intoxicated condition, a minor, or who is known or suspected by him or her to
have acquired and be disposing of the articles unlawfully.



(Ord. 09-2640, passed 11-16-09)



§ 117.35  RECORDS TO BE KEPT.



   (A)   Record books.



      (1)   Every licensee under this chapter shall keep and
preserve a record book, in which shall be legibly written in ink an accurate
description in the English language, of all articles pawned and the amount of
money loaned thereon; the time of the transaction; the name, address,
telephone number, age, color, height, weight, complexion, style of beard or
mustache, any visible distinctive marks or conditions, style of dress of the
person pawning the articles; and the number of the pawn ticket issued.



      (2)   The record book required to be kept by division (A)(1)
shall be open to inspection at all reasonable times by the police or the
Clerk-Treasurer.



   (B)   Card record for police. In addition to the record book
required by this chapter, all licensees under this chapter shall at the time
of receiving any pawned articles fill out a three-inch by five-inch card for
each article pawned. Each card shall contain the information required to be
kept by licensees under this chapter, and the right thumbprint of the person
pawning or selling the article; if the right thumb is missing, any of the
person’s fingerprints may be used. The thumbprint shall be made in the
manner approved by the Police Department and shall not be blurred or
obliterated. The licensees shall mail these cards to the Police Department no
later than the next business day after the item of personal property is
received.



   (C)   List of serialized articles. In addition to the above records,
every licensee under this chapter shall provide a list of serialized articles
that have been acquired by transfers from any location other than the city to
the Police Department no later than the next business day after the articles
are received.



(Ord. 09-2640, passed 11-16-09)



§ 117.36  RETENTION OF ACQUIRED PERSONAL PROPERTY.



   All personal property received by a licensee under this chapter shall
be held intact by the licensee for at least seven business days after the
licensee has mailed a copy of the record required to be maintained under
state law, which details the item of personal property received, to the
Police Department. Whenever any licensee receives written notice, either from
the Police Department or from an individual, that someone is maintaining a
claim of right to possession of the personal property adverse to the
licensee, the licensee shall keep the personal property in his or her
possession for 30 days or turn it over to the Police Department if so
required by the Police Department. Once notice of an adverse claim to the
article has been given under this section, the article shall be held for 30
days, during which legal proceedings may be commenced to determine who is
entitled to the property. If the matter is not settled or legal proceedings
have not been commenced within 30 days, the property shall be returned to the
pawnbroker by the Police Department if held by them.



(Ord. 09-2640, passed 11-16-09)



§ 117.37  SERIAL NUMBERS REQUIRED.



   No pawnbroker shall accept as collateral security or for purchase any
property of the type given manufacturer’s serial numbers or other
identifying insignia unless the property shall have plainly visible thereon
the manufacturer’s serial number or other identifying insignia.



(Ord. 09-2640, passed 11-16-09)



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 117.45  ELECTRONIC INVENTORY-TRACKING AND PHOTOGRAPHS REQUIRED.



   (A)   Electronic inventory-tracking. Each and every owner or
operator of a pawnshop, pawnbroker and dealer in secondhand goods and junk
doing business in the city, shall, within one year of the adoption of this
section, maintain an electronic inventory-tracking system with the entity
designated by the Police Department which is capable of delivery and
transmission of all statutorily-required information via computer.



   (B)   Photographing valuable metals. In addition to maintaining the
information described in division (A), a pawnshop, pawnbroker and dealer in
secondhand goods and junk doing business in the city shall take and upload to
the online entity designated by the Police Department a photograph of:



      (1)   The person from whom the article is being purchased; and



      (2)   The article itself.



(Ord. 09-2640, passed 11-16-09)  Penalty, see § 117.99



§ 117.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter for which
another penalty is not provided shall be subject to § 10.99.



   (B)   The owner or agent of a junk yard in or upon which a violation
shall exist shall have their junk yard license revoked.  If the owner or
agent continues after notification shall constitute a separate offense.  The
violation shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $2,500 for any one
offense.



   (C)   Any and all violations of § 117.45 shall be punishable by a
fine of no less than $2,500 for a first time offense.



(`81 Code, §117.99)  (Ord. 2057, passed 3-16-92; Am. Ord. 09-2640, passed
11-16-09)



CHAPTER 118:  SPECIAL SALES



Section




General Provisions




   118.01   Definitions



   118.02   Certain acts prohibited



   118.03   Hearings and investigations



   118.04   Exemptions



   118.05   Construction of chapter




License Regulations




   118.10   License required



   118.11   Application



   118.12   Fees



   118.13   Term; renewal



   118.14   Payment of personal property taxes required



   118.15   Duties of licensee



   118.16   Surrender of other business licenses



   118.17   When issuance of license prohibited



   118.18   Licensees operating more than one place of business



   118.19   Revocation of license



   118.20   Suspension of license



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 118.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   FIRE AND OTHER ALTERED GOODS SALE.  A sale held in such a manner as to
reasonably cause the public to believe that the sale will offer goods damaged
or altered by fire, smoke, water, or other means.



   GOODS.  Any goods, wares, merchandise, or other property capable of
being the object of a sale regulated under this chapter.



   PUBLISH, PUBLISHING, ADVERTISEMENT, ADVERTISING.  Any means of
conveying to the public notice of sale or notice of intention to conduct a
sale, whether by word of mouth, letter, newspaper advertisement, magazine
advertisement, handbill, written or printed notice, printed display,
billboard display, or poster, whether in or away from the business location,
radio announcement and any other means, oral or written.



   REMOVAL OF BUSINESS SALE.  A sale held in such a manner as to
reasonably cause the public to believe that the person conducting the sale
will cease and discontinue business at the place of sale upon disposal of the
stock of goods on hand and will then move to and resume business at a new
location in the city or will then continue business from other existing
locations in the city.



   SALE.  Shall mean, but not be limited to, the sale, or an offer to
sell to the public, goods, wares, and merchandise of all kinds and
descriptions on hand and in stock in connection with a declared purpose, as
set forth by advertising on the part of the seller, that the sale is
anticipatory to the termination, closing, liquidation, revision, wind-up,
discontinuance, conclusion, or abandonment of the business in connection with
the sale.  It shall also include any sale advertised to be an adjustment
sale, creditor’s sale, executor’s sale, administrator’s sale, insolvent
sale, insurance salvage sale, mortgage sale, assignee’s sale, adjuster’s
sale, receiver’s sale, loss-of-lease sale, wholesaler’s close-out sale,
creditor’s committee sale, forced-out-of-business sale, removal sale, and
all sales advertised in such a manner as to reasonably convey to the public
that upon the disposal of the stock of goods on hand, the business will cease
and be discontinued.



(`81 Code, § 118.01) 



§ 118.02  CERTAIN ACTS PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful to sell, offer, or expose for sale at any sale
regulated by this chapter, or to list on the inventory required by § 118.11,
any stock which is not the stock of the store or other place, the business of
which is to be closed out by the sale for which a license has been granted
under this chapter; to replenish or add to the stock for the purpose of
disposal at the sale; or to fail, neglect, or refuse to keep accurate and
true records of the initial stock, the stock sold, and the stock on hand.



(`81 Code, § 118.02)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 118.03  HEARINGS AND INVESTIGATIONS.



   The Board of Public Works and Safety shall hold hearings and make
investigations as may be necessary to carry out the provisions and intent of
this chapter.



(`81 Code, § 118.03)  Penalty, see § 10.99



Cross-reference:



   Hearing on revocation of licenses, see § 118.19



§ 118.04  EXEMPTIONS.



   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to or affect the
following persons.



   (A)   Persons acting pursuant to an order or process of a court of
competent jurisdiction.



   (B)   Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as
public officials.



   (C)   Duly licensed auctioneers, selling at auction.



   (D)   Any publisher of a newspaper, magazine, or other publication
who publishes in good faith any advertisement without knowledge of its false,
deceptive, or misleading character, or without knowledge that the provisions
of this chapter have not been complied with.



(`81 Code, § 118.04)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 118.05  CONSTRUCTION OF CHAPTER.



   The provisions of this chapter are intended to augment and be in
addition to the other provisions of this code and other applicable licensing
ordinances of the city.  Where this chapter imposes a greater restriction
upon persons, premises, businesses, or other practices than is imposed by any
other provision of this code or other licensing ordinance of the city, then
this chapter shall control.



(`81 Code, § 118.05)  Penalty, see § 10.99



LICENSE REGULATIONS



§ 118.10  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to publish, announce, or
conduct any sale of the type or kind defined by this chapter without first
obtaining a license therefor in compliance with the provisions of this
chapter.



   (B)   The license shall not be assignable or transferable.



   (C)   The license shall authorize only the type of sale described in
the application at the location named therein.



   (D)   The license shall authorize only the sale of the goods
described in the inventory attached to the application therefor.



(`81 Code, § 118.10)  Penalty, see § 10.99



Cross-reference:



   General license requirements, see Chapter 110



§ 118.11  APPLICATION.



   A person desiring to conduct a sale regulated by this chapter shall
make a written application to the Clerk-Treasurer setting forth and
containing the following information.



   (A)   The true names and addresses of the owners of the goods to be
the object of the sale.



   (B)   The true name and address of the person from whom the owner
purchased the goods to be sold and the price therefor, and if not purchased,
the manner of the acquisition.



   (C)   A description of the place where the sale is to be held.



   (D)   The nature of the occupancy, whether by lease or sublease, and
the effective date of termination of the occupancy.



   (E)   The dates of the period of time in which the sale is to be
conducted.



   (F)   A full and complete statement of the facts in regard to the
sale, including the reason for the urgent and expeditious disposal of goods
thereby, and the manner in which the sale will be conducted.



   (G)   The means to be employed in advertising the sale, together
with the proposed content of any advertisement.



   (H)   A complete and detailed inventory of the goods to be sold at
the sale as disclosed by the applicant’s records.  The inventory shall be
attached to and become part of the application.



(`81 Code, § 118.11)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 118.12  FEES.



   Any applicant for a license under this chapter shall submit to the
Clerk-Treasurer with his or her application a license fee of $10.  Any
applicant for a renewal license shall submit to the Clerk-Treasurer with his
or her renewal application a renewal fee of $5.



(`81 Code, § 118.12)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 118.13  TERM; RENEWAL.



   (A)   The license issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter
shall authorize the sale described in the application for a period of not
more than 30 consecutive days following the issuance thereof.



   (B)   The license may be renewed in the discretion of the Board of
Public Works and Safety for an additional period of time not exceeding 30
days upon application being made for the renewal; the application shall be
accompanied by a revised inventory showing the items listed on the original
inventory remaining unsold and not listing any goods not included in the
original application and inventory.



(`81 Code, § 118.13)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 118.14  PAYMENT OF PERSONAL PROPERTY TAXES REQUIRED.



   No license authorized under this chapter shall be issued unless
personal property taxes owed by the applicant are paid to the date of the
application for the license.



(`81 Code, § 118.14)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 118.15  DUTIES OF LICENSEE.



   A licensee under this chapter shall perform the following duties.



   (A)   Make no additions whatsoever during the period of the licensed
sale to the stock of goods set forth in the inventory attached to the
application for the license.



   (B)   Refrain from employing any untrue, deceptive, or misleading
advertising.



   (C)   Conduct the licensed sale in strict conformity with any
advertising or holding out incident thereto.



   (D)   Keep available at the place of sale a duplicate copy of the
inventory submitted with the application, and present the duplicate to
inspecting officials upon request.



   (E)   Keep any other goods separate and apart from the goods listed
in the filed inventory as being objects of sale, and make the distinction
clear to the public by placing tags on all inventoried goods in and about the
place of sale, apprising the public of the status of the goods.



   (F)   Display the license issued pursuant to this chapter in a
prominent place on the window of the premises where the sale is to be held so
that it is clearly visible from the exterior of the premises.



   (G)   Keep suitable books and records at the place of sale and make
them available for inspection by the Board of Public Works and Safety or its
authorized representative.



(`81 Code, § 118.15)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 118.16  SURRENDER OF OTHER BUSINESS LICENSES.



   Upon being issued a license under this chapter for a
going-out-of-business sale, the licensee shall surrender to the
Clerk-Treasurer all other business licenses he or she may hold at that time
applicable to the location and goods covered by the application for a license
under this chapter.



(`81 Code, § 118.16)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 118.17  WHEN ISSUANCE OF LICENSE PROHIBITED.



   (A)   Any person who has not been the owner of a business advertised
or described in the application for a license under this chapter for a period
of at least six months prior to the date of the proposed sale shall not be
granted a license under this chapter. However, upon the death of a person
doing business in the city, his or her heirs, devisees, or legatees, or
executor or administrator shall have the right to apply at any time for a
license hereunder.



   (B)   Any person who has held a sale, as regulated under this
chapter, at the location stated in the application, within one year last past
from the date of the application shall not be granted a license under this
chapter.



(`81 Code, § 118.17)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 118.18  LICENSEES OPERATING MORE THAN ONE PLACE OF BUSINESS.



   Where a person applying for a license under this chapter operates more
than one place of business, the license issued shall apply only to the one
store or branch specified in the application and no other store or branch
shall advertise or represent that it is cooperating with it, or in any way
participating in the licensed sale.  The store or branch conducting the
licensed sale shall not advertise or represent that any other store or branch
is cooperating with it or participating in any way in the licensed sale.



(`81 Code, § 118.18)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 118.19  REVOCATION OF LICENSE.



   (A)   A license or renewal thereof issued pursuant to this chapter
may be revoked by the Board of Public Works and Safety after notice and
hearing, for any of the following reasons.



      (1)   Any fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement
contained in the application.



      (2)   Any fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement made as
to the inventory, stock sold, or stock on hand.



      (3)   Any violation of this chapter.



      (4)   Conducting the business licensed under this chapter in
an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace
or to constitute a menace to the health, safety, or general welfare of the
public.



   (B)   Notice of hearing for revocation of a license issued pursuant
to this chapter shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the
grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing.  The notice
shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee at his or her last known
address at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing.



(`81 Code, § 118.19)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 118.20  SUSPENSION OF LICENSE.



   A license issued pursuant to this chapter may be suspended for not more
than five days by the Board of Public Works and Safety upon probable cause
being shown that the license should be revoked.



(`81 Code, § 118.20)  Penalty, see § 10.99



CHAPTER 119:  TAXICABS



Section

   119.36   State chauffeur’s license required

GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 119.01  TAXICAB DEFINED.



   For the purpose of this chapter the following definition shall apply
unless the context  clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   TAXICAB.  A vehicle driven by mechanical power, designed to carry not
more than seven passengers, for public hire within the city.



(`81 Code, § 119.01) 



§ 119.02  SIGNS ON BODY OF TAXICAB.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to use any motor vehicle for
taxicab service unless that vehicle is designated as a taxicab by two or more
colored signs, the signs to be permanently painted of a fast color on the
body of the vehicle.  The signs shall designate the person to which the
vehicle belongs, and shall be readable from a distance of 150 feet or more by
the naked eye of a person of normal vision.



(`81 Code, § 119.02)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.03  RATES DISPLAYED IN TAXICAB.



   Each person running, driving, operating, or making the operation of a
taxicab possible within the city, shall have printed on a card the fare and
rate of transportation of passengers, together with the prevailing schedule
of rates for the taxicab, and the name of the driver.  The card shall be
prominently displayed in each taxicab so that it can readily be seen and read
by all passengers.



(`81 Code, § 119.03)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.04  PREPAYMENT OF FARE; DUTY TO ORDERLY PASSENGERS.



   Every driver of a taxicab for hire shall have the right to demand
payment of the legal fare in advance and may refuse employment until so
prepaid, but no driver of a taxicab shall otherwise refuse or neglect to
convey any orderly person upon request anywhere in the city unless previously
engaged or unable to do so.  No driver of a licensed taxicab shall carry any
other person than the person first employing him or her without the consent
of the first passenger.



(`81 Code, § 119.04)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.05  PASSENGER COMPLAINTS.



   Any person being aggrieved by reason of the conduct or action of any
taxicab driver or owner in the operation of any taxicab licensed under this
chapter may present a complaint to any police officer of the city, and it
shall be the duty of the Police Department to promptly investigate the
complaint and take appropriate action in the premises.



(`81 Code, § 119.05)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.06  LICENSE PLATES AND FORMS TO BE SUPPLIED.



   It shall be the duty of the Clerk-Treasurer to provide all forms and
license plates required by this chapter.



(`81 Code, § 119.06)  Penalty, see § 10.99



TAXICAB LICENSE



§ 119.10  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   No person shall operate for hire, upon the streets of the city, any
taxicab without having obtained a license therefor as provided in this
chapter.



(`81 Code, § 119.10)  Penalty, see § 10.99



Cross-reference:



   General license requirements, see Chapter 110



Statutory reference:



   Authority to regulate vehicles that transport people, see I.C. 
36-9-2-4



§ 119.11  CERTIFICATE  OF PUBLIC CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY.



   (A)   No license for the operation of any taxicab within the city
shall be granted until the person applying for the license has secured from
the Board of Public Works and Safety a certificate certifying that public
convenience and necessity require the operation of the taxicab for hire.



   (B)   In determining public convenience and necessity, the Board of
Public Works and Safety shall consider the number of taxicabs now in
operation in the city, and shall, in the issuance of licenses, prefer those
now operating or owning taxicabs.  In addition, the Board shall consider
whether the demands of the public require the additional taxicab service, the
financial responsibility of the applicant, the number, kind, type, equipment,
and schedule of rates proposed to be charged, traffic conditions on the
streets of the city, whether the additional taxicab service will result in a
greater hazard to the public, and other relative facts that the Board may
deem advisable or necessary.  The decision and judgment of the Board on the
question of public necessity and convenience shall be conclusive.



(`81 Code, § 119.11)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.12  INSPECTION OF VEHICLE.



   No taxicab for hire shall be licensed under the provisions of this
chapter until it has been thoroughly and carefully inspected and examined and
found to be in a thoroughly safe condition.  The Chief of Police of the city
is hereby authorized and empowered to make, or cause to be made, the
inspection and shall certify in writing to the Board of Public Works and
Safety the results of the inspection.



(`81 Code, § 119.12)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.13  WAITING ROOM REQUIRED.



   No person shall be granted a license under the provisions of this
chapter  for  the  operation  of any  taxicab  within the  city unless
he or she shall during the time of the operation maintain a waiting room with
sufficient seating capacity to accommodate customers and passengers. The
waiting room shall be maintained at all times in a clean and orderly manner
and with sufficient heating capacity to properly heat the room.



(`81 Code, § 119.13)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.14  INSURANCE COVERAGE.



   (A)   Before the Board of Pubic Works and Safety shall issue a
license under the provisions of this chapter to operate a taxicab for hire,
the prospective licensee shall file with the Board a certificate executed by
a duly authorized officer of an insurance company authorized to write
insurance in the state to the effect that a policy of insurance has been
issued to the licensee for the taxicab, is in full force and effect, the
premium has been paid as required, together with a true copy of the policy
contract or certificate of insurance.



   (B)   The policy of insurance for each licensed taxicab shall be in
the sum of $10,000, conditioned for the payment of any final judgments
recovered against any person for the death or injury of persons caused in the
operation, maintenance, use, or defective condition of the taxicab; further,
the policy may be limited to the sum of $20,000 to more than one person, and
may limit the liability of the insurer to $5,000 for damages to or
destruction of property.



   (C)   In the event the maximum liability of the insurance company
under the policy shall be reduced by any recovery in any amount, the
licensee, before operating the taxicab, shall re-comply with the provisions
of this section with respect to insurance on the taxicab the same as if no
policy of insurance thereon had been issued.



   (D)   Any insurance company whose policy has been so filed pursuant
to this section may file a notice in the office of the Board of Public Works
and Safety of its intention to terminate and cancel the policy of insurance
and give notice thereof to the named licensee. After ten days of filing,
unless the licensee or owner shall re-comply with the provisions of this
chapter with respect to insurance, the licensee or owner shall cease to
operate or  cause to be operated within the city the taxicab for hire, the
license issued therefor shall be automatically revoked, and liability on the
policy of insurance shall cease and terminate.  However, the liability of
the insurance company under the cancelled or revoked policy for any act or
omission of the licensee or owner occurring prior to the effective date of
cancellation shall not be discharged or impaired thereby.



(`81 Code, § 119.14)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.15  APPLICATION.



   All  applications  for licenses for taxicabs for hire  shall be made
by the owner to the Board of Public  Works and Safety upon blanks to be
furnished by the Board and the application shall contain the full name and
address of the owner, the length of time the vehicle has been in use, the
number of persons it is capable of carrying, and the model, serial number,
and motor number of the vehicle.



(`81 Code, § 119.15)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.16  FEES.



   Any person operating a taxicab for pay or hire within the city shall,
before so doing, procure from the Clerk-Treasurer a license to do so, for
which he or she shall pay to the Clerk-Treasurer as follows.



   (A)   For the first automobile so operated, the sum of $200.



   (B)   For the second and each additional automobile so operated, the
sum of $5.



(`81 Code, § 119.16)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.17  ISSUANCE; DUPLICATES.



   (A)   If, upon the inspection required by § 119.12, the taxicab is
found to be of lawful construction and in proper condition in accordance with
the provisions of this chapter and when so licensed, there shall be delivered
to the owner, in addition to the license, a card of the size and form
prescribed by the Board of Public Works and Safety.



      (1)   The card shall contain the official city license number
of the taxicab, together with the date of inspection and a statement to the
effect that in case of any complaint the Police Department shall be notified,
giving both the state and city license numbers of the vehicle.



      (2)   The card shall be signed by the Clerk of the Board of
Public Works and Safety and shall contain blank spaces upon which entry may
be made of the date of every inspection of the vehicle by the inspector
designated by the Police Department.



      (3)   The license card shall be of a distinctly different
color each year and shall contain the name of the person owning the taxicab
and the state and city license numbers issued therefor.



   (B)   Upon the payment of the sum of $l to the Clerk-Treasurer and
furnishing proof by affidavit of the loss or destruction of the license or
such license card, a duplicate shall immediately be issued to the licensee
with the notation thereon that it is a duplicate.



(`81 Code, § 119.17)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.18  LICENSE RECORD.



   The Police Department shall keep a complete and public record of the
issuance of each license under this chapter and all renewals, suspensions,
and revocations thereof.  It shall be the duty of the Police Department to
maintain a constant vigilance over all taxicabs for hire to see that they are
kept in a condition of continued fitness for public use.  From time to time,
or on complaint of any citizen, or at any time the Police Department may deem
it necessary, taxicabs shall be inspected or caused to be inspected by the
Police Department.



(`81 Code, § 119.18)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.19  LICENSE PLATES.



   When a license under the provisions of this chapter has been granted,
the licensee shall affix to the taxicab so licensed a small plate which shall
bear the city license number of the vehicle.  The registration of the
license numbers shall be under the control of the Clerk-Treasurer and the
design of the license plates shall be changed annually.  All licenses issued
by the Board of Public Works and Safety under this chapter, unless sooner
revoked as provided in § 119.21, shall expire on December 31 of each year.



(`81 Code, § 119.19)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.20  TRANSFERS OF OWNERSHIP.



   Upon the transfer of ownership of any taxicab, the Board of Public
Works and Safety may, where the transferor requests, validate by appropriate
endorsement thereon the license for the taxicab for use on another taxicab to
be designated by the transferor.



   (A)   This provision shall likewise apply where the licensee shall
produce satisfactory evidence that the taxicab, through destruction or
otherwise, has ceased to be used as a taxicab.



   (B)   Upon the transfer of ownership of any taxicab where the
transferee indicates that the vehicle is to continue in use as a taxicab, the
Board of Public Works and Safety may, by appropriate endorsement thereon,
validate the license in the hands of the transferee.



   (C)   Upon the death of any person holding a taxicab license under
this chapter, and upon proof of the death, the Board of Public Works and
Safety may, at the request of the deceased’s personal representative,
validate by appropriate endorsement thereon the license in the hands of the
person in whose name title to the taxicab has vested by reason of the
death.  In no case, however, shall any transfer be made, as herein provided,
unless and until the transferee in all other respects complies with the terms
and provisions of this chapter.



(`81 Code, § 119.20)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.21  SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION.



   Any taxicab license granted under the terms and provisions of this
chapter may be suspended or revoked by the Board of Public Works and Safety,
if the taxicab shall, with the knowledge and consent of the owner, be engaged
in immoral or illegal business in violation of any provision of this code,
other city ordinance, or state or federal law.



(`81 Code, § 119.21)  Penalty, see § 10.99



Cross-reference:



   Duties of licensee, see § 119.34



DRIVER’S LICENSE



§ 119.25  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   No person shall act as a driver of a taxicab licensed under the
provisions of this chapter without having obtained a license to do so as
provided in this subchapter.



(`81 Code, § 119.25)  Penalty, see § 10.99



Cross-reference:



   General license requirements, see Chapter 110



§ 119.26  PREREQUISITES FOR DRIVER’S LICENSE.



   Each applicant for a driver’s license under the provisions of this
subchapter shall be licensed as a chauffeur under the provisions of the laws
of the state; shall have attained the age of 21 years; shall have sound
physique and good eyesight and not be subject to epilepsy, vertigo, heart
trouble, or any other infirmity of body or mind which might render him or her
unfit for the safe operation of a public vehicle; shall be able to read and
write the English language; shall be clean in dress and person and not
addicted to the use of intoxicating liquors or narcotics, and shall produce,
on forms provided by the Clerk-Treasurer, affidavits establishing his or her
good reputation from two reputable citizens of the city.



(`81 Code, § 119.26)  Penalty, see § 10.99



Statutory reference:



   State chauffeur’s license, see I.C.  9-24-4



§ 119.27  APPLICATION.



   (A)   The applicant for a taxicab driver’s license under the
provisions of this subchapter shall fill out upon a blank form to be provided
by the Police Department a statement containing the following information.



      (1)   His or her full name, residence, and place of residence
for five years previous to the date of his or her application.



      (2)   His or her age, color, height, color of eyes and hair,
place of birth, length of time he or she has resided in the city, whether a
citizen of the United States, the place of his or her previous employment,
and whether married or single.



      (3)   Whether he or she has ever been convicted of a felony
and, if convicted, whether he or she has previously been licensed as a
taxicab driver, and, if so, when and where.



      (4)   Whether his or her license has ever been revoked and for
what cause.



   (B)   This statement shall be signed and sworn to by the applicant
and filed with the Police Department as a permanent record.



   (C)   Each applicant for a taxicab driver’s license under the
provisions of this subchapter shall file with his or her application two
recent photographs of himself or herself of a size which may be easily
attached to the license, one of which shall be attached to the license when
issued, and the second filed, together with the application, with the Police
Department.



(`81 Code, § 119.27)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.28  INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANTS.



   The investigation of all applications for licenses as taxicab drivers
under the provisions of this subchapter shall be conducted by the Police
Department and when the investigation is completed, the application shall be
forwarded by the Chief of Police, with his or her recommendation endorsed
thereon, to the Board of Public Works and Safety.



(`81 Code, § 119.28)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.29  EXAMINATION OF APPLICANTS.



   Each applicant for a taxicab driver’s license under the provisions of
this subchapter shall be examined within ten days after filing his or her
application by the person designated by the Chief of Police as to his or her
knowledge of the provisions of this chapter, traffic regulations, and
geography of the city, and if the result of the examination is
unsatisfactory, the applicant shall be refused a license.  Each applicant
shall, if required by the Police Department, demonstrate his or her skill and
ability to safely handle the vehicle by driving it through a crowded section
of the city accompanied by an inspector designated by the Chief of Police.



(`81 Code, § 119.29)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.30  ISSUANCE.



   Upon satisfactory fulfillment of the requirements of this chapter and
upon approval of the Board of Public Works and Safety, the Clerk-Treasurer
shall issue to the applicant therefor a taxicab driver’s license which
shall be in a form so as to contain the photograph and signature of the
licensee.  Taxicab drivers’ licenses shall be issued as of January 1 of
each year.



(`81 Code, § 119.30)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.31  AUTHORITY OF POLICE DEPARTMENT.



   The Police Department is authorized and empowered to establish
additional rules and regulations governing the issuance of taxicab drivers’
licenses not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter that may be
necessary and reasonable.



(`81 Code, § 119.31)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.32  DISPLAY OF LICENSE.



   Every taxicab driver licensed under the provisions of this subchapter
shall have his or her license, together with his or her photograph,
conspicuously displayed on the inside of his or her taxicab  so that it may
be easily seen by occupants of the taxicab.



(`81 Code, § 119.32)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.33  RENEWAL.



   The renewal of a taxicab driver’s license from year to year may be
obtained upon the application of the licensee by appropriate endorsement by
the Chief of Police recommending renewal.  A taxicab driver, in applying for
renewal of a license, shall make the application upon a form to be furnished
by the Clerk- Treasurer entitled Application for Renewal of Taxicab
Driver’s License, which shall be filled out with the full name and address
of the applicant, together with a statement of the date upon which his or her
original license was granted and the number thereof.



(`81 Code, § 119.33)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.34  DUTIES OF LICENSEE.



   (A)   It shall be the duty of every person licensed under this
subchapter and driving or operating a taxicab to be courteous, to refrain
from swearing, loud talk or boisterous conduct, to drive his or her motor
vehicle carefully and in full compliance with all traffic laws and ordinances
and regulations or orders of the Police Department of the city and the Board
of Public Works and Safety, and to deal honestly with the public and with his
or her employer.



   (B)   Upon the violation of any of the provisions of this section,
upon the recommendation of the Chief of Police, the Board of Public Works and
Safety may suspend or revoke the license of any offending taxicab driver as
provided in this chapter.



(`81 Code, § 119.34)  Penalty, see § 10.99



Cross-reference:



   Suspension and revocation of taxicab license, see § 119.21



§ 119.35  PERMITTING EMPLOYEES TO DRIVE WITHOUT LICENSE.



   No person shall permit any employee to operate a public taxicab for
hire within the city without the employee having obtained a license as a
taxicab driver as provided in this subchapter.



(`81 Code, § 119.35)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 119.36  STATE CHAUFFEUR’S LICENSE REQUIRED.



   No taxicab owner or operator shall permit any person not having a valid
state chauffeur’s license or any driver whose state chauffeur’s license
has been suspended or revoked to operate any taxicab within the city.



(`81 Code, § 119.36)  Penalty, see § 10.99



Statutory reference:



   State chauffeur’s license provisions, see I.C. 9-24-4



CHAPTER 120:  CABLE REGULATIONS



Section



   120.01   Adoption of rules and regulations



   120.02   Definition



   120.03   Public hearing



   120.04   Period of review of rates



   120.05   Period of review of basic service tier and equipment



   120.06   Resolution on reviews



   120.07   Content of records



   120.08   Refunds



   120.09   Failure to comply



§ 120.01  ADOPTION OF RULES AND REGULATIONS.



   The City Council hereby adopts the rules and regulations set forth by
the Federal Communications Commission pursuant to Section 623 (b) of the
Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992 (47 USC
543(b)) for the review of the basic service tier of cable television services
and equipment necessary for the provision of such service tier.



(`81 Code, § 120.01)  (Ord. 93-2128, passed 11-15-93)



§ 120.02  DEFINITION.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   BASIC SERVICE TIER OF CABLE TELEVISION SERVICES.  A separately
available service tier to which subscription is required for access to any
other tier of service, including as a minimum, but not limited to, all
signals of domestic television broadcast stations provided to any subscriber,
(except a signal secondarily transmitted by satellite carrier beyond the
local service area of such station, regardless of how such signal is
ultimately received by the cable system) any public, educational, and
governmental programming required by the franchise to be carried on the basic
tier, and any additional video programming signals or service added to the
basic tier by the cable operator.  Equipment necessary to provide the basic
tier of service shall be defined as those items of associated equipment
necessary for the reception of basic cable service by a subscriber,
including, but not limited to converter boxes, remote control units,
additional outlets, and installation.



(`81 Code, § 120.02)  (Ord. 93-2128, passed 11-15-93)



§ 120.03  PUBLIC HEARING.



   (A)   The city shall provide the grantee of the cable television
franchise, the public, and interested parties with an opportunity to be heard
at a public hearing before the City Council. Upon 14 days written notice to
the grantee of the cable television franchise of the time and place of the
public hearing, the notice shall indicate that the purpose of the public
hearing is to receive the views of the grantee and interested parties  on
issues pertaining  to regulation of the basic service tier of cable
television services and equipment necessary to provide the basic tier of
service. Notice of the public hearing shall be published in a local newspaper
of general circulation at least ten days before the date of this hearing. An
agenda for the public hearing shall be posted in a public place at least
seven days prior to the public hearing.



   (B)   Upon the adoption of this chapter and the certification of the
city by the Federal Communications Commission, the city shall immediately
notify the cable operator by certified mail, return receipt requested, that
the city intends to regulate subscriber rates charged for the basic service
tier and associated equipment as authorized by the Cable Television Consumer
Protection and Competition Act of 1992.  Upon receipt of the notice by the
city, the Cable Operator shall, within 30 days, file with the city its
current rates for the basic service tier and associated equipment along with
any additional documentation justifying the reasonableness of its rates.



(`81 Code, § 120.03)  (Ord. 93-2128, passed 11-15-93)



§ 120.04  PERIOD OF REVIEW OF RATES.



   (A)   The city shall establish that the period for review of rates
of the basic service tier of cable television services and the equipment
necessary to provide the basic tier of service shall be 30 days from the
submission by the grantee of the cable television franchise of Federal
Communications Commission Form 393.  If the City Council takes no action
within 30 days from the date the cable operator files its basic cable rates
with the city, the proposed rates will continue in effect.



   (B)   In the event that additional time for review of the Federal
Communications Commission Form 393 submitted by grantee is necessary, the
City  Council or their designee shall issue a brief written order prior to
the end of the 30-day review period, with a copy of the order to be sent by
Certified United States Mail to the grantee, providing for an additional
90-day period for review of rates of the basic service tier and the equipment
necessary to provide the basic tier of service.  During the extended review
period and before taking action on the proposed rate, the City Council shall
hold at least one public hearing in which interested citizens may express
their views and record objections.



(`81 Code, § 120.04)  (Ord. 93-2128, passed 11-15-93)



§ 120.05  PERIOD OF REVIEW OF BASIC SERVICE TIER AND EQUIPMENT.



   (A)   The city shall establish that the period for review of the
basic service tier of cable television services and the equipment necessary
to provide the basic tier of service shall be 90 days from the submission by
the grantee of information and forms prescribed by the Federal Communications
Commission for a showing of cost-of-service, as defined by the Federal
Communications Commission.



   (B)   In the event that additional time for review of the
cost-of-service showing submitted by the grantee is necessary, the City
Council  or their designee shall issue a brief written order prior to the
end of the 90-day review period with a copy of the order to be sent by
Certified United States Mail to the grantee, providing for an additional
150-day period for review of rates of the basic service tier and the
equipment necessary to provide the basic tier of service.  During the
extended review period and before taking action on the proposed rate, the
City Council shall hold at least one public hearing in which interested
citizens may express their views and record objections.



(`81 Code, § 120.05)  (Ord. 93-2128, passed 11-15-93)



§ 120.06  RESOLUTION ON REVIEWS.



   (A)   Upon completion of its review of the proposed rates for the
basic service tier of cable television services and the equipment necessary
to provide the basic tier of service, the City Council shall adopt its
decision by formal resolution.  The resolution shall indicate the reasons
for the decision.  Upon passage of the resolution, the City Council shall
publish the resolution in pamphlet form.



   (B)   In the event that the cable operator’s proposed rates exceed
the reasonable rate standard as established by the Federal Communications
Commission, the City Council may order that rates shall be reduced by
rollbacks or refunds to subscribers, in the manner prescribed by the Federal
Communications Commission.



(`81 Code, § 120.06)  (Ord. 93-2128, passed 11-15-93)



§ 120.07  CONTENT OF RECORDS.



   In considering information provided by the grantee as a part of review
of its rates for the basic service tier of cable television services and the
equipment necessary to provide the basic tier of service, the city shall not
disclose to the public the content of any records, forms, reports,
calculations, or other documents as provided which the grantee has indicated
as being of a proprietary interest of constituting a trade secret in
nature.  The municipal officer responsible for administration of the Indiana
Freedom of Information Act shall retain the right to determine the validity
of the grantee’s claim of proprietary interest or trade secrecy in
accordance with the provisions of the Indiana Freedom of Information Act.



(`81 Code, § 120.07)  (Ord. 93-2128, passed 11-15-93)



§ 120.08  REFUNDS.



   The city may order the cable operator to refund to subscribers a
portion of previously paid rates under the following circumstances:



   (A)   A portion of the previously paid rates have been determined to
be in excess of the permitted basic cable service tier charge or above the
actual cost of equipment; or



   (B)   The cable operator has failed to comply with a valid rate
order issued by the city.



(`81 Code, § 120.08)  (Ord. 93-2128, passed 11-15-93)



§ 120.09  FAILURE TO COMPLY.



   Failure by the cable operator to comply with the terms and conditions
established by this chapter, shall constitute a violation of the city code
(the Cable Television Franchise Ordinance).  Penalties for such violations
are subject to the conditions of § 10.99.



(`81 Code, § 120.09)  (Ord. 93-2128, passed 11-15-93)



TITLE XIII:  GENERAL OFFENSES



      Chapter




         130.   GENERAL OFFENSES




CHAPTER 130:  GENERAL OFFENSES



Section



   130.01   Begging



   130.02   Defacing public or private property



   130.03   Unlawful noise



   130.04   Sleeping in public places



   130.05   Discharge of weapons



   130.06   Possession of weapons by minors



   130.07   False alarms of automatic alarm systems
