§ 150.004  SCOPE OF DISTRICT REGULATIONS.



   (A)   The regulations set forth by this chapter within each district
shall be minimum regulations and shall apply uniformly to each class or kind
of structure, or land, except as hereinafter provided more particularly.



   (B)   No building, structure, or land shall hereafter be used or
occupied, and no building or structure or part thereof shall hereafter be
erected, constructed, reconstructed, moved, or structurally altered except in
conformity with all of the regulations specified for the district in which it
is located.



   (C)   No building or other structure shall hereafter be erected or
altered to exceed the height or bulk; to accommodate or house a greater
number of families; to occupy a greater percentage of lot area; or to have
narrower or smaller rear yards, front yards, side yards, or other open
spaces; other than as herein required, or in any other manner contrary to the
provisions of this chapter.



   (D)   No part of a yard or other open space, or off-street parking
or loading space required in connection with any building for the purpose of
complying with this chapter, shall be included as part of a yard, open space,
or off-street parking or loading space similarly required for any other
building.



   (E)   No yard or lot existing at the time of passage of this chapter
shall be reduced in dimension or area below the minimum requirements set
forth herein.  Yards or lots created after the effective date of this
chapter shall meet at least the minimum requirements established by this
chapter.



(`81 Code, § 150.004)  (Ord. 1613, passed 12-15-75)  Penalty, see §
150.999



§ 150.005  MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS ESTABLISHED.



   (A)   In their interpretation and application, the provisions of
this chapter shall be held to be minimum requirements, adopted for the
promotion of the public health, safety, morals, or general welfare.



   (B)   Whenever the provisions of this chapter require a greater
width or size of yards, courts, or other spaces, or require a lower height of
building or less number of stories, or require a greater percentage of lot to
be left unoccupied, or impose other higher standards than are required in any
other ordinance, the provisions of this chapter shall govern.



   (C)   Wherever the provisions of any other ordinance require a
greater width or size of yards, courts, or other open spaces, or require a
lower height of building or a lesser number of stories, or require a greater
percentage of lot to be left unoccupied, or impose other higher standards
than are required by the provisions of this chapter, the provisions of the
ordinance shall govern.



(`81 Code, § 150.005)  (Ord. 1613, passed 12-15-75)  Penalty, see §
150.999



DISTRICTS AND BOUNDARIES



§ 150.015  ESTABLISHMENT OF DISTRICTS.



   (A)   It shall be a responsibility of the Plan Commission to
recommend the boundaries of the various original districts and appropriate
regulations to be enforced therein.  The Commission shall make a preliminary
report and hold public hearings before submitting its final report, and the
City Council shall not hold its public hearings or take action until it has
received the final report of the Commission.



   (B)   For the purpose of this chapter there are created 12 types of
districts by which the jurisdictional area defined in § 150.003 shall be
divided.



      (1)   S-1 Suburban Residence District.



      (2)   R-1 One-Family Residence District.



      (3)   R-2 Two-Family Residence District.



      (4)   R-3 Multiple-Family Residence District.



      (5)   B-1 Central Business District.



      (6)   B-2 Highway Commercial District.



      (7)   B-3 Neighborhood Commercial District.



      (8)   M-1 Light Industrial District.



      (9)   —2 Heavy Industrial District.



      (10)   C-1 Conservancy District.



      (11)   GFP General Floodplain District.



      (12)   PD Planned Development District.



(`81 Code, § 150.010)  (Ord. 1613, passed 12-15-75)  Penalty, see §
150.999



§ 150.016  OFFICIAL ZONING MAP.



   (A)   The city is divided into zones or districts as shown on the
official zoning map, which, together with all explanatory matter thereon, is
adopted by reference and declared to be a part of this chapter.  The
official zoning map shall be identified by the signature of the Mayor,
attested by the Clerk-Treasurer, and shall bear the seal of the city under
the following words:  “This is to certify that this is the official zoning
map referred to in Section 601 of Ordinance Number 1613 of the City of
Shelbyville, Indiana”, together with the date of the adoption of the
ordinance.



   (B)   If, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, changes
are made in the district boundaries or other matter portrayed on the official
zoning map, the changes shall be entered on the official zoning map promptly
after the amendment has been approved by the City Council, with an entry on
the official zoning map as follows:  “On (date), by official action of the
City Council the following (change) changes were made in the official zoning
map: (brief description of nature of change)”, this entry to be signed by
the Mayor and attested by the City Clerk-Treasurer.



      (1)   No amendment to this chapter which involves matter
portrayed on the official zoning map shall become effective until after the
change and entry has been made on the map.



      (2)   No changes of any nature shall be made in the official
zoning map or matter shown thereon except in conformity with the procedures
set forth in this chapter.



      (3)   Any unauthorized change of whatever kind by any person
or persons shall be considered a violation of this chapter and punishable as
provided by § 150.999.



      (4)   Regardless of the existence of purported copies of the
official zoning map which may, from time to time, be made or published, the
official zoning map which shall be located in the office of the City
Clerk-Treasurer shall be the final authority as to the current zoning status
of land and water areas, buildings, and other structures in the city.



   (C)   In the event the official zoning map becomes damaged,
destroyed, lost, or difficult to interpret because of the nature or number of
changes and additions, the City Council may, by resolution, adopt a new
official zoning map which shall supersede the prior map.



      (1)   The new official zoning map may correct drafting or
other errors or omissions in the prior map, but no correction shall have the
effect of amending the original map or any subsequent amendment thereof.



      (2)   The new official zoning map shall be identified by the
signature of the Mayor, attested by the City Clerk-Treasurer, and bear the
seal of the city under the following words:  “This is to certify that this
Official Zoning Map supersedes and replaces the Official Zoning Map adopted
(date of adoption of map being replaced) as part of Ordinance No. 1613 of the
City of Shelbyville, Indiana.”



      (3)   Unless the prior official zoning map has been lost, or
has been totally destroyed, the prior map or any significant parts remaining,
shall be preserved, together with all available records pertaining to its
adoption or amendment.



(`81 Code, § 150.011)  (Ord. 1613, passed 12-15-75)  Penalty, see §
150.999



§ 150.017  INTERPRETATION OF DISTRICT BOUNDARIES.



   Where uncertainty exists as to the boundaries of districts as shown on
the official zoning map, the following rules shall apply.



   (A)   Boundaries indicated as approximately following the center
lines of streets, highways, or alleys shall be construed to follow the center
lines.



   (B)   Boundaries indicated as approximately following platted lot
lines shall be construed as following the lot lines.



   (C)   Boundaries indicated as approximately following city limits
shall be construed as following the city limits.



   (D)   Boundaries indicated as following railroad lines shall be
construed to be midway between the main tracks.



   (E)   Boundaries indicated as following shore lines shall be
construed as following the shore lines, and in the event of change in the
shore line shall be construed as moving with the actual shore line. 
Boundaries indicated as approximately following the center line of streams,
rivers, canals, lakes, or other bodies of water shall be construed to follow
the center lines as established on the effective date of the chapter.



   (F)   Boundaries indicated as parallel to or extensions of features
indicated in divisions (A) through (E) above shall be so construed. 
Distances not specifically indicated on the official zoning map shall be
determined by the scale of the map.



   (G)   Where physical or cultural features existing on the ground are
at variance with those shown on the official zoning map, or in other
circumstances not  covered by divisions (A) through (F) above, the Board of
Zoning Appeals shall interpret the district boundaries.



   (H)   Where a district boundary line divides a lot which was in
single ownership at the time of passage of this chapter, the Board of Zoning
Appeals may permit, as a special exception, the extension of the regulations
for either portion of the lot not to exceed 50 feet beyond the district line
into the remaining portion of the lot. However, no special exception shall be
permitted in a General Floodplain (GFP) or Conservancy District (C-1).



(`81 Code, § 150.012)  (Ord. 1613, passed 12-15-75)  Penalty, see §
150.999



RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS



§ 150.025  S-1 SUBURBAN RESIDENCE DISTRICT.



   (A)   The intent of a Suburban Residence District (S-1) is to
provide low density residential areas together with some compatible uses.



   (B)   The following principal uses and structures shall be permitted
in a Suburban Residence District (S-1).



      (1)   Single-family dwellings.



      (2)   Horticulture uses and the raising of crops.



   (C)   The following accessory uses and structures shall be permitted
in a Suburban Residence District (S-1).



      (1)   Home occupations and professional offices.



      (2)   Mobile homes, under the prescribed conditions of §
150.111.



      (3)   Accessory structures normally appurtenant to the
permitted uses within the space limits of this district.



   (D)   After the provisions of this chapter relating to special
exceptions have been fulfilled, the Board of Zoning Appeals may permit as
special exceptions in Suburban Residence Districts (S-1).



      (1)   Churches, synagogues, and temples.



      (2)   Nursery, primary, intermediate, and secondary schools.



      (3)   Public recreational and park facilities.



      (4)   Golf courses and country clubs.



      (5)   Cemeteries.



      (6)   Utility substations.



      (7)   Public libraries and museums.



      (8)   Day nurseries.



   (E)   All other uses and structures which are not specifically
permitted or not permissible as special exceptions shall be prohibited from
Suburban Residence Districts (S-1).



   (F)   The minimum lot area and lot area per dwelling unit shall be
9,000 square feet, and the minimum lot width shall be 80 feet.



   (G)   There shall be a front yard of not less than a depth of 25
feet.  There shall be a rear yard of not less than a depth of 20 feet. Each
side yard shall not be less than ten feet.



   (H)   The maximum lot coverage for all buildings shall not be more
than 35% of the total area.



   (I)   The height of all buildings and structures shall not exceed 35
feet.



(`81 Code, § 150.015)  (Ord. 1613, passed 12-15-75)  Penalty, see §
150.999



§ 150.026  R-1 ONE-FAMILY RESIDENCE DISTRICT.



   (A)   The intent of One-Family Residence Districts (R-1) is to
provide for medium density residential use areas together with certain
prescribed compatible uses.



   (B)   The following principal uses and structures shall be permitted
in One-Family Residence Districts (R-1).



      (1)   Single-family dwellings.



      (2)   Horticulture uses and the raising of crops.



   (C)   The following accessory uses and structures shall be permitted
in One-Family Residence Districts (R-1).



      (1)   Home occupations and professional offices.



      (2)   Mobile homes under the prescribed conditions of §
150.111.



      (3)   Accessory structures normally appurtenant to the
permitted uses within the space limits of this district.



   (D)   After the provisions of this chapter relating to special
exceptions have been fulfilled, the Board of Zoning Appeals may permit as
special exceptions in One-Family Residence Districts (R-1).



      (1)   Colleges and universities.



      (2)   Churches, synagogues, and temples.



      (3)   Nursery, primary, intermediate, and secondary schools.



      (4)   Public recreational and park facilities.



      (5)   Golf courses and country clubs.



      (6)   Cemeteries.



      (7)   Utility substations.



      (8)   Convalescent, nursing, and rest homes.



      (9)   Medical and other health facilities.



      (10)   Governmental services.



      (11)   Day nurseries.



   (E)   All other uses and structures which are not specifically
permitted or not permissible as special exceptions shall be prohibited from
One-Family Residence Districts (R-1).



   (F)   The minimum lot area shall be 8,000 square feet.  The minimum
lot width shall be 60 feet.



   (G)   There shall be a front yard of not less than a depth of 20
feet.  There shall be a rear yard of not less than a depth of 20 feet. Each
side yard shall not be less than ten feet.



   (H)   The maximum lot coverage for all buildings shall not be more
than 40% of the total lot area.



   (I)   The height of all buildings and structures shall not exceed 35
feet.



   (J)   Wherever a dwelling is to be erected, altered, or enlarged, on
a lot less than 60 feet in width as authorized by this section, the side yard
width requirement may be decreased to not less than four feet, and the sum of
the two side yards may be decreased one foot for each three feet that the lot
is less than 60 feet in width.



   (K)   (1)   Where, in an established residential neighborhood, a
front yard of lesser depth than required by this chapter exists in the front
yards of the majority of homes in the neighborhood, and it is more in
character of the existing neighborhood to allow the new construction of a
dwelling that has the lesser front yard setback than is required by this
chapter, new residential structures may be allowed a front yard setback
reduction of no more than ten feet from the required setback distance.  In
no instance, however, may the reduced setback allow for any structure to
encroach upon an established or existing utility, utility easement or
right-of-way, drainage easement or street and/or alley right-of-way or
ingress/egress easement.  Further, no reduced setback shall be allowed which
would create any hazard due to reduced visibility caused by the structure. 
It shall be within the authority of the Planning Department to determine the
allowable reduction of the front yard setback.



      (2)   Further, where an existing, non- conforming structure is
located, and its non- conformity is based upon an insufficient side yard
setback; additions to the residential structure may be aligned with the
existing structure’s side yard setback.  No additions may be built closer
than four feet from the property line.  In no case should the allowed
setback reductions violate the lot coverage requirements as set forth in this
chapter.



      (3)   If, in the opinion of the Planning Department, there is
no reduction warranted in the front yard and side yard setback, or the person
feels aggrieved with the decisions of the Planning Department, the person or
persons desiring the reduction may apply for relief through the Board of
Zoning Appeals as set forth in § 150.114.



   (L)   (1)   Where, in an established residential neighborhood, an
application has been made to allow the construction of an accessory
structure, as defined in § 150.003, and the required setbacks cannot be met,
either because the lot is a non-conforming lot, or the existing principal
structure is oriented on the lot in such a manner that the placement of the
accessory structure in order to meet the setback requirements would render
the structure useless or undesirable, it shall be within the authority of the
Zoning Administrator to determine an allowable reduction in setbacks.  The
following factors will be considered when making that determination:



         (a)   Prevailing neighborhood conditions concerning
similar matters.



         (b)   The location of any existing or proposed drainage
or utility easement.



         (c)   The potential for reduced access to adjoining
parcels.



         (d)   Potential for any conflict concerning public
safety issues



      (2)   Further, the reduction in setback requirements, if
determined to be warranted by the Zoning Administrator, shall not be reduced
to allow the accessory structure to be built closer than four feet to the
side yard lot line, nor shall the rear yard setback be reduced to less than
ten  feet from the rear yard lot line.



      (3)   Should the applicant of a set back adjustment
application feel aggrieved by the Zoning Administrator’s decision, an
appeal may be filed with the Board of Zoning Appeals as set forth in §
150.162.



(`81 Code, § 150.016)  (Ord. 1613, passed  12-15-75; Am. Ord. 2063, passed
5-4-92; Am. Ord. 00-2359, passed 6-5-00; Am. Ord. 02-2424, passed 2-21-02) 
Penalty, see § 150.999



§ 150.027  R-2 TWO-FAMILY RESIDENCE DISTRICT.



   (A)   The intent of Two-Family Residence Districts is to provide for
medium density residential use areas of one and two-family houses, together
with certain prescribed compatible uses.



   (B)   The following principal uses and structures shall be permitted
in Two-Family Residence Districts (R-2).



      (1)   Single-family dwellings.



      (2)   Two-family dwellings.



   (C)   The following accessory uses and structures shall be permitted
in Two-Family Residence Districts (R-2).



      (1)   Home occupations and professional offices.



      (2)   Mobile homes under the prescribed conditions of §
150.111.



      (3)   Accessory structures normally appurtenant to the
permitted uses within the space limits of this district.



   (D)   After the provisions of this chapter relating to special
exceptions have been fulfilled, the Board of Zoning Appeals may permit as
special exceptions in Two-Family Residence Districts (R-2).



      (1)   Townhouses.



      (2)   Mobile home parks.



      (3)   Colleges and universities.



      (4)   Churches, synagogues, and temples.



      (5)   Nursery, primary, intermediate, and secondary schools.



      (6)   Public recreational and park facilities.



      (7)   Golf courses and country clubs.



      (8)   Cemeteries.



      (9)   Utility substations.



      (10)   Convalescent, nursing, and rest homes.



      (11)   Medical and other health facilities.



      (12)   Governmental services.



      (13)   Day nurseries.



   (E)   All other uses and structures which are not specifically
permitted or not permissible as special exceptions shall be prohibited from
Two-Family Residence Districts (R-2).



   (F)   The minimum lot area shall be 6,000 square feet.  If there
are to be multiple units in one structure, the minimum lot area per dwelling
unit shall be 3,500 square feet per dwelling unit.  The minimum lot width
shall be 60 feet.



   (G)   There shall be a front yard of not less than a depth of 20
feet.  There shall be a rear yard of not less than a depth of 20 feet. Each
side yard shall not be less than seven feet.



   (H)   The maximum lot coverage for all buildings shall not be more
than 40% of the total lot area.



   (I)   The height of all buildings and structures shall not exceed 35
feet.



   (J)   (1)   Where, in an established residential neighborhood, a
front yard of lesser depth than required by this chapter exists in the front
yards of the majority of homes in the neighborhood, and it is more in
character of the existing neighborhood to allow the new construction of a
dwelling that has the lesser front yard setback than is required by this
chapter, new residential structures may be allowed a front yard setback
reduction of no more than ten feet from the required setback distance.  In
no instance, however, may the reduced setback allow for any structure to
encroach upon an established or existing utility, utility easement or
right-of-way, drainage easement or street and/or alley right-of-way or
ingress/egress easement.  Further, no reduced setback shall be allowed which
would create any hazard due to reduced visibility caused by the structure. 
It shall be within the authority of the Planning Department to determine the
allowable reduction of the front yard setback.



      (2)   Further, where an existing, non- conforming structure is
located, and it’s non- conformity is based upon an insufficient side yard
setback; additions to the residential structure may be aligned with the
existing structure’s side yard setback.  No additions may be built closer
than four feet from the property line.  In no case should the allowed
setback reductions violate the lot coverage requirements as set forth in this
chapter.



      (3)   If, in the opinion of the Planning Department, there is
no reduction warranted in the front yard and side yard setback, or the person
feels aggrieved with the decisions of the Planning Department, the person or
persons desiring the reduction may apply for relief through the Board of
Zoning Appeals as set forth in § 150.114.



   (K)   (1)   Where, in an established residential neighborhood, an
application has been made to allow the construction of an accessory
structure, as defined in § 150.003, and the required setbacks cannot be met,
either because the lot is a non-conforming lot, or the existing principal
structure is oriented on the lot in such a manner that the placement of the
accessory structure in order to meet the setback requirements would render
the structure useless or undesirable, it shall be within the authority of the
Zoning Administrator to determine an allowable reduction in setbacks.  The
following factors will be considered when making that determination:



         (a)   Prevailing neighborhood conditions concerning
similar matters.



         (b)   The location of any existing or proposed drainage
or utility easement.



         (c)   The potential for reduced access to adjoining
parcels.



         (d)   Potential for any conflict concerning public
safety issues.



      (2)   Further, the reduction in setback requirements, if
determined to be warranted by the Zoning Administrator, shall not be reduced
to allow the accessory structure to be built closer than four feet to the
side yard lot line, nor shall the rear yard setback be reduced to less than
ten  feet from the rear yard lot line.



      (3)   Should the applicant of a set back adjustment
application feel aggrieved by the Zoning Administrator’s decision, an
appeal may be filed with the Board of Zoning Appeals as set forth in §
150.162.



(`81 Code, § 150.017)  (Ord. 1613, passed 12-15-75; Am. Ord. 97-2259,
passed 7-7-97; Am. Ord. 00-2359, passed 6-5-00; Am. Ord. 02-2424, passed
2-21-02)  Penalty, see § 150.999



§ 150.028  R-3 MULTIPLE-FAMILY RESIDENCE DISTRICT.



   (A)   The intent of Multiple-Family Residence Districts (R-3) is to

prescribed compatible uses.

in Multiple-Family Residence Districts (R-3).



      (1)   Single-family dwellings.



      (2)   Two-family dwellings.



      (3)   Multiple-family dwellings.



      (4)   Townhouses.



   (C)   The following accessory uses and structures shall be permitted
in Multiple-Family Residence Districts (R-3).



      (1)   Home occupations and professional offices.

150.111.



      (3)   Accessory uses and structures normally appurtenant to
the permitted uses and structures when established within the space limits of
this district.



   (D)   After the provisions of this chapter relating to special
exceptions have been fulfilled, the Board of Zoning Appeals may permit as
special exceptions in Multiple-Family Residence Districts (R-3).



      (1)   Mobile home parks.



      (2)   Funeral homes and funeral chapels.



      (3)   Churches, synagogues, and temples.



      (4)   Nursery, primary, intermediate, and secondary schools.



      (5)   Convalescent, nursing, and rest homes.



      (6)   Medical and other health facilities.



      (7)   Public recreational and park facilities.



      (8)   Golf courses and country clubs.



      (9)   Communication and utility uses, and utility substations.



      (10)   Rooming and boarding houses.



      (11)   Governmental services.



      (12)   Day nurseries.



   (E)   All other uses and structures which are not specifically
permitted or not permissible as special exceptions shall be prohibited from
Multiple-Family Residence Districts (R-3).



   (F)   The minimum lot area shall be 6,000 square feet.  If there
are to be multiple units in one structure, the minimum lot area per dwelling
unit shall be 2,000 square feet per dwelling unit.  The minimum lot width
shall be 60 feet.



   (G)   There shall be a front yard of not less than a depth of 20
feet.  There shall be a rear yard of not less than a depth of 15 feet. 
Each side yard shall not be less than seven feet.



   (H)   The maximum lot coverage for all buildings shall not be more
than 50% of the total lot area.



   (I)   The height of all buildings and structures shall not exceed 45
feet.



   (J)   (1)   Where, in an established residential neighborhood, a
front yard of lesser depth than required by this chapter exists in the front
yards of the majority of homes in the neighborhood, and it is more in
character of the existing neighborhood to allow the new construction of a
dwelling that has the lesser front yard setback than is required by this
chapter, new residential structures may be allowed a front yard setback
reduction of no more than ten feet from the required setback distance.  In
no instance, however, may the reduced setback allow for any structure to
encroach upon an established or existing utility, utility easement or
right-of-way, drainage easement or street and/or alley right-of-way or
ingress/egress easement.  Further, no reduced setback shall be allowed which
would create any hazard due to reduced visibility caused by the structure. 
It shall be within the authority of the Planning Department to determine the
allowable reduction of the front yard setback.



      (2)   Further, where an existing, non- conforming structure is
located, and it’s non- conformity is based upon an insufficient side yard
setback; additions to the residential structure may be aligned with the
existing structure’s side yard setback.  No additions may be built closer
than four feet from the property line.  In no case should the allowed
setback reductions violate the lot coverage requirements as set forth in this
chapter.



      (3)   If, in the opinion of the Planning Department, there is
no reduction warranted in the front yard and side yard setback, or the person
feels aggrieved with the decisions of the Planning Department, the person or
persons desiring the reduction may apply for relief through the Board of
Zoning Appeals as set forth in § 150.162.



   (K)   (1)   Where, in an established residential neighborhood, an
application has been made to allow the construction of an accessory
structure, as defined in § 150.003, and the required setbacks cannot be met,
either because the lot is a non-conforming lot, or the existing principal
structure is oriented on the lot in such a manner that the placement of the
accessory structure in order to meet the setback requirements would render
the structure useless or undesirable, it shall be within the authority of the
Zoning Administrator to determine an allowable reduction in setbacks. The
following factors will be considered when making that determination:



         (a)   Prevailing neighborhood conditions concerning
similar matters.



         (b)   The location of any existing or proposed drainage
or utility easement.



         (c)   The potential for reduced access to adjoining
parcels.



         (d)   Potential for any conflict concerning public
safety issues



      (2)   Further, the reduction in setback requirements, if
determined to be warranted by the Zoning Administrator, shall not be reduced
to allow the accessory structure to be built closer than four feet to the
side yard lot line, nor shall the rear yard setback be reduced to less than
ten feet from the rear yard lot line.



      (3)   Should the applicant of a set back adjustment
application feel aggrieved by the Zoning Administrator’s decision, an
appeal may be filed with the Board of Zoning Appeals as set forth in §
150.162.

BUSINESS DISTRICTS



§ 150.035  B-1 CENTRAL BUSINESS DISTRICT.



   (A)   The intent of Central Business District (B-1) is to provide a
commercial area for those establishments serving the general shopping needs
of the trade area and in particular, those establishments customarily
oriented to the pedestrian shopper.  The grouping of uses is intended to
strengthen the central business area as the urban center of trade, service,
governmental, and cultural activities.



   (B)   The following principal uses and structures shall be permitted
in the Central Business District (B-1):



      (1)   Appliance service establishments;



      (2)   Artisan/craft shops;



      (3)   Bus passenger terminals and taxicab transportation;



      (4)   Beauty and barber services;



      (5)   Churches, synagogues, and temples; welfare and
charitable services; and other public or semi-public associations and meeting
places;



      (6)   Clinics;



      (7)   Financial institutions, except drive- through;



      (8)   Funeral homes;



      (9)   Government buildings;



      (10)   Hotels/motels;



      (11)   Libraries;



      (12)   Lodges/private clubs;



      (13)   Multiple-family residential units located in a business
establishment provided they are located above the first floor;



      (14)   Museums/galleries;



      (15)   Newspaper publishing;



      (16)   Professional, personal, educational and business
services/offices;



      (17)   Parking lots;



      (18)   Radio-TV stations/studios;



      (19)   Restaurants, except drive-ins or drive- through;



      (20)   Retail stores for general merchandise;



      (21)   Schools;



      (22)   Taverns/night clubs;



      (23)   Theaters;



      (24)   Wholesale businesses;



      (25)   On-site signs.



   (C)   The following accessory uses and structures shall be permitted
in the Central Business District (B-1l):  Accessory uses and structures
normally appurtenant to the permitted uses and structures, when established
within the space limits of this district, excluding warehousing.



   (D)   After the provisions of this chapter relating to special
exceptions have been fulfilled, the Board of Zoning Appeals may permit as
special exceptions in the Central Business District (B-1):



      (1)   Auto sales and service;



      (2)   Financial institutions with drive- throughs;



      (3)   Automobile service stations;



      (4)   Heliports;



      (5)   Hospitals;



      (6)   Nursing homes;



      (7)   Private recreation;



      (8)   Public recreation;



      (9)   Public utility structures;



      (10)   Restaurants with drive-ins or drive-throughs;



      (11)   Warehouses and storage;



      (12)   Retail sales of lumber and other building materials,
farm equipment, marine-craft, aircraft, trailers, farm and garden supplies,
and greenhouses.



   (E)   All other uses and structures which are not specifically
permitted or not permissible as special exceptions shall be prohibited from
the Central Business District (B-1).



   (F)   The minimum lot area shall be 2,400 square feet.  The minimum
lot width shall be 20 feet.



   (G)   There shall be a front yard of not less than a depth of 25
feet.  There shall be a rear yard of not less than a depth of 20 feet. Each
side yard shall be not less than seven feet, provided that all buildings
located on lots adjacent to a residential district shall be located so as to
conform on the adjacent side with the side yard requirements for the adjacent
residential district.



   (H)   The maximum lot coverage for all buildings shall not be more
than 90% of the total lot area.



   (I)   The height of all buildings and structures shall not exceed 35
feet.

§ 150.036  B-2 HIGHWAY COMMERCIAL DISTRICT.



   (A)   The intent of the Highway Commercial District (B-2) is to
provide commercial areas for those establishments which can function most
satisfactorily in an area directly related to a major vehicular circulation
route due to the nature of the merchandise handled and the display space
required, particularly items requiring expansive display area such as motor
vehicles, trailers, and farm implements; the method of transport required of
the purchaser for the merchandise handled, particularly goods customarily
traded in bulk such as lumber or feed requiring access for the customer to
the sales area; primary dependence upon vehicular, as opposed to pedestrian,
access such as drive-in facilities and all types of automotive and farm
implement service; or the clientele toward which the establishment is
primarily oriented, particularly travelers on the highway.



   (B)   The following principal uses and structures shall be permitted
in Highway Commercial Districts (B-2):



   Except residential, all uses permitted in the B-1 District, and the
following:



      (1)   Automobile sales and service;



      (2)   Beauty and barber services;



      (3)   Drive-through financial institutions;



      (4)   Drive-in restaurants;



      (5)   Automobile service stations;



      (6)   Shopping centers and malls;



      (7)   Veterinary clinics and kennels;



      (8)   Warehouses and storage;



      (9)   Retail sales of lumber and other building materials,
farm equipment, marine-craft, aircraft, trailers, farm and garden supplies,
and greenhouses.



   (C)   The following accessory uses and structures shall be permitted
in Highway Commercial Districts (B-2):  Accessory uses normally appurtenant
to the permitted principal uses and structures, when established in
conformance with space limits of this district.



   (D)   All other uses and structures which are not specifically
permitted or not permissible as special exceptions shall be prohibited from
Highway Commercial districts (B-2).  After the provisions of this chapter
relating to special exceptions have been fulfilled, the Board of Zoning
Appeals may permit as special exceptions in the Highway Commercial Business
District (B-2):



      (1)   Car washes;



      (2)   Boarding or lodging houses;



      (3)   Heliports;



      (4)   Hospitals;



      (5)   Motor freight terminals, garaging, equipment maintenance
and fueling facilities;



      (6)   Nursing homes;



      (7)   Private recreation;



      (8)   Public recreation;



      (9)   Public utility structures;



      (10)   Truck sales and service;



      (11)   Mobile home sales.



   (E)   The minimum lot area shall be 6,000 square feet.  The minimum
lot width shall be 60 feet.



   (F)   There shall be a front yard of not less than a depth of 40
feet.  There shall be a rear yard of not less than a depth of 20 feet. 
There shall be a side yard of a depth not less than ten feet.



   (G)   The maximum lot coverage for all buildings shall not be more
than 50% of the total lot area.



   (H)   The height of all buildings and structures shall not exceed 35
feet.

passed 9-15-97; Am. Ord. 97-2271, passed 11-3-97; Am. Ord. 99-2344, passed
10-18-99)  Penalty, see § 150.999



§ 150.037  B-3 NEIGHBORHOOD COMMERCIAL DISTRICT.



   (A)   The intent of Neighborhood Commercial Districts (B-3) is to
provide limited but convenient retail trade and service establishments to
neighborhood areas.



   (B)   The following principal uses and structures shall be permitted
in Neighborhood Commercial Districts (B-3):



      (1)   Attached dwellings;



      (2)   Automobile parking;



      (3)   Beauty and barber services;



      (4)   Boarding or lodging houses;



      (5)   Churches, synagogues, and temples; welfare and
charitable services; and other public or semi-public associations and meeting
places;



      (6)   Clinics;



      (7)   Funeral homes;



      (8)   Hospitals;



      (9)   Laundering, dry cleaning and dyeing, provided that there
is no processing on the premises;



      (10)   Multiple family dwellings;



      (11)   Professional offices, studios;



      (12)   Public parks or recreational facilities;



      (13)   Repair services, limited to small appliances, watch,
clock, or jewelry and garments, including pressing and alterations;



      (14)   Retail sales of general merchandise;



      (15)   Schools, except trade or technical;



      (16)   Restaurants, excluding drive-in or drive-through;



      (17)   On-site signs.



   (C)   The following accessory uses and structures shall be permitted
in Neighborhood Commercial  Districts (B-3):  Accessory uses and structures
normally appurtenant to the permitted uses and structures, when established
within the space limits of this district.



   (D)   All other uses and structures which are not specifically
permitted or not permissible as special exceptions shall be prohibited from
Neighborhood Commercial Districts (B-3).  After the provisions of this
chapter relating to special exceptions have been fulfilled, the Board of
Zoning Appeals may permit as special exceptions in the Neighborhood Business
District (B-3):



      (1)   Financial institutions;



      (2)   Automobile service stations;



      (3)   Government buildings;



      (4)   Lodges or private clubs;



      (5)   Museums/galleries;



      (6)   Public utility structures;



      (7)   Trade and technical schools;



      (8)   Restaurants with drive-throughs;



      (9)   Taverns and nightclubs.



   (E)   All other uses and structures which are not specifically
permitted or not permissible as special exceptions shall be prohibited from
Neighborhood Commercial Districts (B-3).



   (F)   The minimum lot area shall be 6,000 square feet.  The minimum
lot width shall be 60 feet, concerning new construction.



   (G)   There shall be a front yard of not less than a depth of 25
feet.  There shall be a rear yard of not less than a depth of 20 feet. Each
side yard shall be not less than ten feet, provided all buildings located on
lots adjacent to a residential district shall be located so as to conform on
the adjacent side with the side yard requirements for the adjacent
residential district.



   (H)   The maximum lot coverage for all buildings shall not be more
than 70% of the total lot area.



   (I)   The height of all buildings and structures shall not exceed 35
feet.



   (J)   Any new industry, building in an area not previously
commercial in use, shall submit to the Board of Public Works and Safety an
environmental impact study including the standards provided in § 150.035
(F)(1) through (9).
