GENERAL PROVISIONS



    § 151.01  TITLE.



       This chapter may be known and cited as “The Subdivision
Regulation Chapter of the City of Shelbyville, Indiana,” to the same effect
as if the full title were stated.



(`81 Code, § 151.001)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75)



§ 151.02  DEFINITIONS.



       For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   ACCESSORY STRUCTURE. As defined in § 150.003.



   AS-BUILT CONSTRUCTION PLANS. Drawings made after the completion of
improvements which identify how the improvements were constructed on site.
These drawings shall contain all the information required by the office of
the Plan Commission.



   BONDS. Any form of security including a cash deposit, surety bond,
collateral, property or instrument of credit in an amount and form
satisfactory to the Board of Public Works and Safety. All BONDS shall be
approved by the Board of Public Works and Safety whenever required in this
section.



   BUILDING.  As defined in § 150.003.



       CONSTRUCTION PLAN. The maps, drawings, and textual description
accompanying a subdivision plat showing the specific location and design of
improvements to be installed in a development in accordance with the
requirements enumerated in this section.



   DETAILED STANDARDS. A set of engineered drawings which shall be
approved by the Board of Public Works and Safety, the City’s Engineer,
Waste Water Treatment Plant Superintendent and Street Commission. The
drawings will be amended as the aforementioned persons see fit, and the most
current set of standards shall be applied to all development within the
jurisdictional areas of the city.



   DEVELOPER HANDBOOK. A manual which contains certain technical
information, procedures and other requirements for development within the
jurisdictional area of the city as approved by the Plan Commission. The
DEVELOPER HANDBOOK shall be amended as necessary, and the most current
information shall be applied to all development within the jurisdictional
areas of the city. A fee, as established by the office of the Plan Commission
shall, be charged for each copy of the DEVELOPER HANDBOOK.



       GRADING PLAN. A drawing at a scale of no more than 50 feet one
inch, showing a plan view of the entire development including existing
topography and contours, at no more than a two foot interval, and a grading
plan to establish the proposed elevations. Proposed swails should be shown
including a typical cross-section, inverts and slopes, along with the minimum
building pad elevations based upon 20% fall in the first ten feet and 2% fall
during the remaining distance to the property line or drainageway.



   IMPROVEMENTS. Any alteration to the land or physical constructions
associated with subdivision and building site development.



   INFRASTRUCTURE. The fixed public works and facilities necessary in a
community such as sewers, sidewalks, curbs, gutters, water systems, streets,
swails, other drainage systems and parking areas.



   INFRASTRUCTURE IMPROVEMENTS.  The construction of any infrastructure
as defined.



   LOCATION IMPROVEMENT PERMIT. A certificate issued by the Office of the
Plan Commission permitting a person, firm or corporation to erect, construct,
enlarge, alter, repair, move, improve or convert any building or structure
within the jurisdictional area of the city, or cause same to be done. No
LOCATION IMPROVEMENT PERMIT shall be issued until the approval of an
application has been granted. The issuance of a LOCATION IMPROVEMENT PERMIT
shall deem that the project in question is in compliance with the
requirements of the Zoning Code as required in § 150.158.



   MAINTENANCE BOND. Shall be posted of a bond, as defined, in the amount
of 10% of the performance bond.



   PERFORMANCE BOND. A bond in the amount which is 125% of the bid price
of the improvements to be completed in conjunction with the project for which
bonding is being provided.



   STREET.  A public way for purposes of vehicular travel, including the
entire area within the right-of-way.



      (1)   ARTERIAL STREETS.  A street primarily for through
traffic.



      (2)   PARKWAYS. Those streets which are similar to an
arterial, but with a large median for landscaping and somewhat slower traffic
flow.



      (3)   COLLECTOR STREETS. Those streets which carry or will
carry intermediate volumes of traffic from local access streets to arterial
streets.



      (4)   LOCAL ACCESS STREETS. Those streets which are used or
will be used primarily for access to abutting properties and which carry or
will carry limited volumes of traffic.



      (5)   ALLEYS. Minor ways which are used primarily for
vehicular service access to the backs or to the sides of properties which
otherwise abut on streets.



   SUBDIVIDER. An individual, firm, corporation, partnership, association,
syndicate, trust or legal entity that executes the application and initiates
the proceedings for the subdivision of land in accordance with the provisions
of this chapter. The SUBDIVIDER need not be the owner of the property;
however, he or she may be an agent of the owner or have sufficient
proprietary rights in the property to represent the owner.



   SUBDIVISION. The division of a lot, tract, or parcel of land into two
or more lots, plots, sites, or other division of land for the purpose of
either immediate or future sale or building development. It also includes a
resubdivision of lands or lots, and the establishment or dedication of a
road, highway, street, or alley through a tract of land.



   TECHNICAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE. The Technical Advisory Committee is
hereby created and shall consist of the following members as invited by the
Director of the Plan Commission.



      (1)   The Plan Commission Director.



      (2)   The Commissioner of the Waste Water Treatment Department.



      (3)   The Superintendent of the Waste Water Treatment
Department.



      (4)   A designee of the SBC Cable Company.



      (5)   A designee of the Indiana American Water Company.



      (6)   A designee of the Indiana Gas Company.



      (7)   A designee of the Cinergy (PSI) Company.



      (8)   A designee of the County Soil and Conservation district.



      (9)   A designee of the Fire Department.



      (10)   A designee of the Police Department.



      (11)   A designee of Ameritech.



      (12)   A designee of Shelby County REMC.



      (13)   A designee of the County Surveyor’s Office.



      (14)   A designee of the City Council.



      (15)   A designee of the Plan Commission.



   The Technical Advisory Committee has the following responsibilities and
duties in connection with the implementation of this section:



   To review and evaluate applications and site plans for plat approval,
and/or site development, which are presented to the Plan Commission, City
Council and Board of Public Works and Safety, pursuant to procedures set
forth further in this section, and to make recommendations to the
aforementioned bodies concerning the plat or development in question.



(`81 Code, § 151.002)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75; Am. Ord. 96-2230, passed
12-16-96; Am. Ord. 97-2252, passed 6-2-97; Am. Ord. 98-2293, passed 2-17-99)



§ 151.03  JURISDICTION.



       Pursuant to state law, the provisions of this chapter shall apply
within the corporate limits of the city, as they may be amended by subsequent
annexation.



(`81 Code, § 151.003)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75)



§ 151.04  APPLICATION.



       Any plat hereafter made, for each subdivision or each part
thereof lying within the jurisdiction of this chapter, shall be prepared,
presented for approval, and recorded as herein prescribed. The regulations 
contained herein shall apply to the subdivision of a lot, tract, or parcel of
land into two or more lots, tracts, or some other division of land for the
purpose of sale or of building development, whether immediate or future,
including the resubdivision or replatting of land or lots.



(`81 Code, § 151.004)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75)



§ 151.05  MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS ESTABLISHED.



       In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this
chapter shall be held to be minimum requirements, adopted for the promotion
of public health, safety, morals, or general welfare. Wherever the
requirements of this chapter are at variance with any other lawfully adopted
rules, regulations, ordinances, deed restrictions, or covenants, the most
restrictive or that imposing the higher standards, shall govern.



(`81 Code, § 151.005)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75)



MINIMUM STANDARDS OF DESIGN



    § 151.10  SUITABILITY OF LAND FOR SUBDIVISION DEVELOPMENT.



       (A)   The Plan Commission shall impose the following general
requirements and compel subdividers to comply with the following principles
of design in the layout and construction of subdivisions. All plats shall be
prepared by a registered professional engineer or land surveyor.



   (B)   If the Plan Commission finds that land proposed to be
subdivided is unsuitable for subdivision development due to flooding, bad
drainage, steep slopes, rock formations, and other conditions that may
increase the danger to health, life, or property or aggravate erosion or
flood hazards; and, if from adequate investigations, conducted by all the
public agencies concerned, it has been determined that in the best interest
of the public the land should not be platted and developed for the purpose
proposed, the Plan Commission shall not approve the land for subdivision
unless adequate methods are formulated by the subdivider for meeting the
problems that will be created by the subdivision and development of the land.



   (C)   The Plan Commission may refuse to approve what it considers to
be scattered or premature subdivision of land which would involve danger or
injury to the public health, safety, welfare, or prosperity by reason of lack
of adequate water supply, schools, proper drainage, good roads and
transportation facilities, or other public services; or which would
necessitate an excessive expenditure of public funds for the supply of such
services (such as undue maintenance costs for adequate roads) .



(`81 Code, § 151.010)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75) Penalty, see § 151.99



§ 151.11  STREETS.



       (A)   Conformity to the circulation plan. The widths and
locations of all street rights-of-way in a proposed subdivision shall conform
to the major streets and highways plan.



   (B)   Street extensions.



      (1)   The street layout of the proposed subdivision shall
provide for the continuation or projection of streets and alleys already
existing in areas adjacent to the area being subdivided.



      (2)   Where, at the determination of the Plan Commission, it
is desirable to provide street access to adjoining properties, proposed
streets shall be extended by dedication to the boundaries of the
properties.  Where the Plan Commission deems it necessary, dead-end streets
shall be provided with a temporary turn-around approved by the Plan
Commission.



      (3)   The street system for the proposed subdivision shall
provide for extending existing streets at the same or greater width, but in
no case shall a street extension be of less width than the minimum width
required in these regulations for a street in its category.



   (C)   Dedication of right-of-way for new streets. The dedication of
right-of-way for new streets measured from lot line to lot line shall be as
shown on the major streets and highways plan, or, if not shown thereon, shall
meet the following standards.



 

 
Street Type
 
Minimum Dedicated Right-of-Way Width


      (1)
 
Parkway
 
120+ feet


 
Major arterial
 
100  feet


 
Arterial
 
70  feet


 
Collector
 
60  feet


 
Local access
 
50  feet



 



      (2)   All streets classified as arterial streets by the major
streets and highways plan shall have all points of access approved by the
Plan Commission.  Marginal access streets or frontage roads may be required
by the Plan Commission for subdivisions fronting on arterial streets.



      (3)   Through proposed business areas, street widths shall be
increased ten feet on each side if needed, to provide parking without
interfering with normal traffic movements.



   (D)   Dedication of right-of-way for existing streets. 
Subdivisions platted along existing streets after the effective date of this
chapter shall dedicate additional right-of-way, if necessary, to meet the
minimum street width requirements set forth in division (C) of this section.



      (1)   The entire minimum right-of-way width shall be dedicated
where the subdivision is on both sides of an existing street. When the
subdivision is located on only one side of an existing street, ½ of the
required right-of-way width, measured from the center line of the existing
roadway, shall be dedicated.



      (2)   Dedication of one-half of the rights-of- way for
proposed streets along the boundaries of land proposed for subdivision shall
be prohibited.



   (E)   Intersections.  In general, all streets shall join each other
so that for a distance of at least 100 feet the street is approximately at
right angles to the street it joins.



      (1)   Street curb intersections shall be rounded by radii of
at least 20 feet.  Wherever necessary to permit the construction of a curb
having a desirable radius without reducing the sidewalk at a street corner to
less than normal width, the property line at the street corner shall be
rounded or otherwise set back sufficiently to permit the curb construction.



      (2)   No lot or other parcel of land which abuts on, and has
access to, either a collector or a local access street shall have a service
drive, curb cut, or other means of access to an arterial street within 75
feet of the right-of-way of any street which intersects the arterial street
on the side on which the lot or parcel is located.



   (F)   Curves in streets, horizontal and vertical.



      (1)   A tangent at least 100 feet long shall be introduced
between reverse curves on arterial streets.



      (2)   Where there is a deflection angle of more than ten
degrees in the alignment of a street, a curve with a radius adequate to
insure safe sight distance shall be made.  The minimum radii of curves shall
be as follows.



 

Street Type
 
Minimum Curve Radius


Arterial
 
400 feet


Collector
 
200 feet


Local access
 
100 feet



 



      (3)   Every change in grade shall be connected by a vertical
curve constructed so as to afford a minimum sight distance of 200 feet.



            (a)   Sight distance is the measurement from a
driver’s eyes, which are assumed to be 3.75 feet above the pavement
surface, to an object six inches high on the pavement.



            (b)   Profiles of all streets showing natural and
finished grades, drawn to an approved scale, will be required by the Plan
Commission and the Board of Public Works and Safety.



   (G)   Street grades and elevations.  Street grades shall conform to
the following standards.



 

Street Type
 
Percent Grade


Arterial
 
5


Collector
 
5


Local access
 
7



 



      (1)   All streets shall be designed so to provide for the
discharge of surface water from the pavement and from the right-of-way by
grading and drainage.  For adequate drainage, the minimum street grade shall
be not less than .5%.



      (2)   The Plan Commission shall not approve the streets which
will be subject to inundation or flooding.



         (a)   All streets must be located at elevations which
will make them flood-free in the event of a 100-year flood.



         (b)   Where flood conditions exist, the Plan Commission
shall require profiles and elevations of streets in order to determine the
advisability of permitting the proposed subdivision activity.



         (c)   Fill may be used in areas subject to flooding in
order to provide flood-free streets, if the fill does not unduly increase
flood heights.



         (d)   Drainage openings shall be designed so as not to
restrict the flow of water and thereby unduly increase flood heights.



   (H)   Marginal access streets.  Where the proposed subdivision
abuts upon or contains an existing or proposed arterial street or highway on
which traffic volumes and vehicular speeds warrant special safety
considerations, the Plan Commission may require that marginal access streets
be provided in order that no lots front directly on the existing or proposed
arterial street or highway.



   (I)   Dead-end (culs-de-sac).  Minor terminal or dead-end streets
or courts which are designed so as to have one end permanently closed shall
not be longer than 600 feet.  Such streets shall be provided at the closed
end with a turnaround having a radius at the outside of the pavement of at
least 50 feet and a radius at the outside of the right-of-way of at least 60
feet.  The cul-de-sac shall be a geometric shape so as to contain a 100-foot
diameter circle.



   (J)   Street names.  Proposed streets which are obviously
extensions of already existing and named streets shall bear the names of the
existing streets.  The name of a proposed street which is not an extension
of an existing street shall not duplicate the name of any existing street,
irrespective of the use of the suffix street, avenue, boulevard, drive,
place, court, lane, road, pike, highway, parkway, or similar suffix.



   (K)   Private streets and reserve strips.  There shall be no
private streets platted within a  subdivision. There shall be no reserve
strips in a subdivision except where their control is definitely vested in
the city or county under conditions approved by the Plan Commission as
authorized in these regulations.



(`81 Code, § 151.011)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75)  Penalty, see § 151.99



§ 151.12  BLOCKS.



   (A)   Block lengths shall not exceed 1,200 feet, or be less than 300
feet, except as the Plan Commission considers necessary to secure efficient
use of land or desired features of street layout.



   (B)   Blocks shall be wide enough to allow two tiers of lots of
minimum depth.  However, where this would require lots to front on an
arterial street or highway or where topographical conditions or the size of
the property prevent two tiers of lots, the Plan Commission may approve a
single tier of lots of minimum depth.



(`81 Code, § 151.012)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75)  Penalty, see § 151.99



§ 151.13  LOTS.



   The following provisions shall pertain; however, modifications may be
permitted in planned unit developments.



   (A)   Lots shall be designated by numbers. Streets, avenues, and
other grounds shall be designated by names or numbers.



   (B)   Relationship to streets.  All lots shall front on a public
street or road for a minimum distance of 50 feet.  However, lots which front
on the turnarounds of permanent dead-end streets shall have a minimum
distance of 50 feet between side property lines at the front building line.



   (C)   Arrangement.  Except where not feasible, side lot lines shall
be at right angles to straight street lines and radial to curved street lines.



   (D)   Dimensions. The size, shape, and orientation of lots shall be
such as the Plan Commission deems appropriate for the type of development and
use contemplated.  Lot dimensions within the jurisdiction of this chapter
shall conform to the requirements of Chapter 150.



   (E)   Building line setback.  The building line to establish yards
for all buildings and lots shall be as provided in Chapter 150.



   (F)   Corner lots.  Corner lots shall have sufficient extra width
to meet the building setback lines of 25 feet from the building line,
established on both the front street and side street.



   (G)   Yard requirements.  Yard requirements for residential
subdivisions or the portions thereof within the jurisdiction of this chapter
shall be the same as the yard requirements set forth in Chapter 150 for the
zoning district or districts in which they are located.



   (H)   Flood hazards.  Land subject to flooding, and land deemed to
be topographically unsuitable for residential development shall not be
platted for residential use or for any other use which may increase the
danger to health, life, or property or aggravate erosion or flood hazards.



      (1)   Such land within the subdivision shall be set aside on
the plat for those uses that will not be endangered by periodic or occasional
inundation contrary to the public welfare.



      (2)   To insure that lots will be located only where they will
provide flood-free house sites, the Board of Public Works and Safety may
require the subdivider to provide elevation and flood profiles sufficient to
demonstrate that the house sites will be completely free from the danger of
flooding.



      (3)   If a stream flows through or adjacent to the proposed
subdivision, the plat plan shall provide for an easement or right-of-way
along the stream for a floodway.



         (a)   For smaller streams, the plan shall also provide
for channel improvement to enable them to carry all reasonable floods within
banks.



         (b)   The floor elevations of houses shall be high
enough to be well above the 100-year flood.



         (c)   The floodway easement shall be wide enough  to
provide for future enlargement of the stream channel as adjacent areas become
more highly developed and run-off rates are increased.



(`81 Code, § 151.013)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75)  Penalty, see § 151.99



§ 151.14  OFF-STREET LOADING  AND PARKING FACILITIES.



   In commercial and industrial subdivisions, in the portions of
residential subdivisions reserved for commercial or industrial uses, and the
lots or parcels platted for commercial or industrial uses, lots or parcels
platted for commercial or industrial sites shall be large enough to provide
for off-street loading and unloading facilities and off-street parking
facilities as provided in § 150.112.



(`81 Code, § 151.014)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75)  Penalty, see § 151.99



§ 151.15  UTILITY AND DRAINAGE EASEMENTS.



   (A)   Easements are required as necessary for poles, wires,
conduits, storm sewers, sanitary sewers, gas mains, water mains, and other
utilities.  In general, street rights-of-way or a 12-foot easement centered
along rear lot lines shall be provided for this purpose.  No structures of
any kind shall be constructed on an easement.



   (B)   Where the Plan Commission deems it necessary for proper
drainage within or through a subdivision, it shall require that a storm water
easement or drainage right-of-way be provided.



(`81 Code, § 151.015)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75)  Penalty, see § 151.99



§ 151.16  COMMUNITY ASSETS.



   In all subdivisions, due regard shall be shown for natural features
such as large trees, unusual rock formations, and water courses; for sites
which have historical significance; and for similar assets which, if
preserved, will add attractiveness and value to the subdivision and to the
community. The Plan Commission may prepare a list of all features which it
deems worthy of preservation.



(`81 Code, § 151.016)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75) Penalty, see § 151.99



    § 151.17  CONFORMANCE WITH ZONING AND OTHER REGULATIONS.



   No final plat of land will be approved unless it conforms with Chapter
150. Whenever there is a variance between the minimum standards set forth in
these regulations and those contained in the Zoning Code, Building Code, or
other official regulations, the highest standard shall apply.



(`81 Code, § 151.017)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75) Penalty, see § 151.99



    § 151.18  PUBLIC OPEN SPACES.



       (A)   A minimum of 4% of the gross area of any subdivision or
planned development shall be reserved for parks and playground sites.



   (B)   Park and playground sites shall be dedicated to the city to be
reserved for public use.



      (1)   The Plan Commission after consulting with the Parks
Department, however, shall have the option to determine whether, to accept
the park site or a contribution to the park and recreation fund of the city
in a sum of money equal to the appraisal of the fair market value of the park
area prior to the time of platting, or the purchase price paid by the
developer if the property was purchased within 12 months of the date the date
of platting. The sum of money collected shall be placed in the park fund of
the city to provide recreational areas and facilities. No plat shall be
approved and no building permit shall be issued by the city within any
subdivision or planned development until either the park site is dedicated to
the city or all contribution monies are paid in full.



      (2)   In the event the city accepts that dedication of land as
park and playground sites, the following standards shall apply.



         (a)   No local open space may be less than 20,000 square
feet in area, nor larger than 12 acres, except when stream valley parks,
storm drainage, utility easements, or green buffers are included with the
written permission of the Plan Commission, or as provided below.



         (b)   Any area or segment of an open space less than 100
feet in width cannot be calculated as local open space unless it is clearly
part of an overall open space system. For example, a linear pedestrian system
linking larger, open spaces could be included in the calculation.



         (c)   A lower minimum than 20,000 square feet or a
higher maximum than 12 acres may be authorized by the Plan Commission,
particularly if practical difficulties or unusual hardship would be entailed
by the application of the required standards. Such difficulties may include
cases in which one area somewhat greater than 12 acres will clearly give
better use than two areas of less than 12 acres each.



         (d)   When open space land is stream valley or
floodplain or without sufficient adequately- sized and reasonably level areas
for selected active recreation use, the city may require that additional land
of a suitable nature be provided even though the total required is more than
the regularly required amount.



         (e)   Developers of adjoining subdivisions may cooperate
in allocating open space for joint use by all residents of the subdivisions
concerned. Where this is done, size, location, and design are subject to Plan
Commission approval.



         (f)   Required local open space must meet the definition
of usable open space. Land in public utility easements may be included in the
open space provision to the full extent that the use of the land is not
restricted for recreation purposes. To the extent that it is restricted,
additional land must be designated by the developer.



         (g)   Although the provision of local open space is
always desirable, there are some situations in which the provision is not
mandatory. These are summarized as follows.



            1.   A lot or tract in a previously approved
subdivision.



            2.   Lot or tract which is too small to
accommodate six dwelling units.



            3.   A single ownership site which is less than ½
acre in size.



         (h)   Upon receipt of an application for a subdivision
or planned development within the city, the Plan Commission Director shall
forward a copy of such application to the Parks Department.



(`81 Code, § 151.018)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75; Am. Ord. 1931, passed
7-5-88; Am. Ord. 1987, passed 4-2-90) Penalty, see § 151.99



§ 151.19 LARGE TRACTS OR PARCELS.



   When land is subdivided into larger parcels than ordinary building
lots, the parcels shall be arranged so as to allow for the opening of future
streets and logical resubdivision.



(`81 Code, § 151.019)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75) Penalty, see § 151.99



IMPROVEMENTS PREREQUISITE TO FINAL PLAT APPROVAL



§ 151.25  MONUMENTS.



   The requirements for the monuments and lot staking are specified and
shall be compiled with as in the detailed standards of the city.



(`81 Code, § 151.025)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75; Am. Ord. 99-2324, passed
4-19-99) Penalty, see § 151.99



§ 151.26 STREETS.



   (A)   Grading specifications. All streets, roads, and alleys shall
be graded to their full widths by the subdivider so that street pavements and
sidewalks can be constructed on the same level plane. Deviation from this
standard due to special topographical conditions will be allowed only with
the special approval of the Plan Commission.



      (1)   Preparation of the subgrade. Before grading is started,
the entire right-of-way area shall be first cleared of all tree stumps,
roots, brush, and other objectionable materials and of all trees not intended
for preservation. The subgrade shall be properly shaped, rolled, and
uniformly compacted to conform with the accepted cross-section and grades.
The subgrade shall be a minimum of three inches of compacted aggregate, as
per engineering specifications.



      (2)   Cuts. In cuts, all tree stumps, boulders, organic
material, soft clay, spongy material, and other objectionable materials shall
be removed to a depth of at least two feet below the graded surface. Rock,
when encountered, shall be sacrificed to a depth of at least 12 inches below
the graded surface.



      (3)   Fills. In fills, all tree stumps, boulders, organic
material, soft clay, spongy material, and other objectionable material shall
be removed to a depth of at least two feet below the natural ground surface.
This objectionable matter, as well as similar matter from cuts, shall be
removed from the right-of-way area and disposed of in such a manner that it
will not become incorporated in fills or hinder proper operation of the
drainage system.



   (B)   Minimum pavement widths. Pavement widths shall be measured
from back of curb, to back of curb.



      (1)   Minimum pavement widths to be provided are as follows.



 

 
Major arterial
 
48 feet and up


 
Arterial
 
36


 
Collector
 
36


 
Local access
 
26



 



      (2)   The Plan Commission shall require up to ten feet of
additional pavement width to accommodate an anticipated heavy use of on
street parking spaces in an R-1 and R-2 zoning district with a density equal
to or greater than 4.0 dwelling units per gross acre.



   (C)   Pavement specifications for streets. The subdivider shall
provide street pavements which shall be designed to carry the expected
traffic and which shall conform with the standard specifications of the State
Highway Commission for portland cement concrete pavement or bituminous
concrete pavement.



   (D)   Curbs and gutters. The subdivider shall provide curbs and
gutters. Curbs shall be constructed in conformance with Standard
Specifications of the State Highway Commission as amended. Backfill shall be
higher than the curb and shall slope toward the curb in order to insure that
surf ace water drains into the storm drainage system.



   (E)   Sidewalks. For the safety of pedestrians in residential and
commercial subdivisions, the subdivider shall build portland cement concrete
sidewalks on both sides of the street to meet the following specifications.



      (1)   Single-family or duplex housing developments. Four feet
wide and four inches thick.



      (2)   Multi-family or group housing developments. Five feet
wide and four inches thick.



      (3)   Commercial developments. Ten feet wide and four inches
thick.



      (4)   Where sidewalks are crossed by driveways, the walks
shall have a minimum thickness of six inches. The time of the installation
shall be negotiated with the Board of Public Works and Safety.



(`81 Code, § 151.026)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75) Penalty, see § 151.99



§ 151.27  UTILITY AND DRAINAGE FACILITIES.



       (A)   Sanitary sewers, storm sewers, water distribution,
electrical, gas, telephone, and communications cable, and other utility lines
shall be installed underground. These utility lines shall be installed in
12-foot wide rear lot easements or they shall be installed within the unpaved
portions of the street right-of-way, except for sanitary and storm sewer
lines which may be installed in the paved portion of the street right-of-way
if it is impossible to install them in the unpaved portion. When it is
impossible to install sanitary and storm sewer lines in the unpaved portion
of the street right-of-way, the following procedure shall be adhered to.
Following the grading of the street, prior to the application of any pavement
base, all utility lines, including service connections, shall be completely
installed, and inspected and approved by the Building Inspector. Where
sanitary and storm sewer lines are to be installed in the unpaved portion of
the street right-of- way, the subdivider may be permitted to delay the
installation of service connections, provided, that at the time these service
connections are installed, they may be installed without breaking or
weakening the existing pavement. Where rock is known to exist beneath the
pavement area at a depth as to interfere with the installation of service
connections, the complete installation of service connections shall be
required prior to the application of any pavement base.



   (B)   Water supply improvements. Where the public water supply is
reasonably accessible or available to the proposed subdivision, as determined
by the Board of Public Works and Safety, the subdivider shall construct a
complete water distribution system which shall adequately serve all lots,
which shall include appropriately spaced fire hydrants, and which shall be
properly connected with the public water supply system. Where a public water
supply system is not reasonably accessible to the subdivision, the subdivider
shall be required to install alternate water supply facilities approved by
the City Engineer. Where individual lot wells are to be installed, lot
dimensions shall meet the approval of the City Council. In any case, water
supply facilities shall be installed as required by standards and
specifications as approved by the County Board of Health.



   (C)   Sanitary sewer improvements. The subdivider shall construct a
complete sanitary sewer system which shall adequately serve all lots and
which shall be properly connected to the public sanitary sewer system. Where
a public sanitary sewer system is not reasonably accessible to the
subdivision, the subdivider shall install alternate sanitary sewer facilities
which shall be approved by the Plan Commission and the County Health Officer.
In any case, sanitary sewer facilities shall be installed as required by
standards and specifications as approved by the State Board of Health. No
connection draining storm-water runoff shall be made to a sanitary sewer.



   (D)   Storm drainage. The subdivider may be required by the Board of
Public Works and Safety to carry away by pipe or open ditch any spring or
surface water that may exist either previous to, or as a result of the
subdivision.



      (1)   These drainage facilities shall be located in the street
right-of-way where feasible, or in perpetual unobstructed easements of
appropriate width.



      (2)   A culvert or other drainage facility shall, in each
case, be large enough to accommodate potential runoff from its entire
upstream drainage area, whether inside or outside the subdivision. Locations
and size of culverts shall be determined when construction plans are
prepared. Where surface storm drainage flow is concentrated, permanently
maintainable facilities, which can include vegetation, shall be provided to
prevent significant erosion and other damage or flooding on site or on
adjacent property.



      (3)   The City Engineer shall approve the design and size of
facility based on anticipated runoff from a ten-year storm under conditions
of total potential development permitted by Chapter 150 in the watershed.



          (4)   The subdivider’s engineer shall also study the
effect of each subdivision on the existing downstream drainage facilities
outside the area of the subdivisions. This study shall be reviewed by the
City Engineer.



      (5)   Where it is anticipated that the additional runoff
incident to the development of the subdivision will overload an existing
downstream drainage facility during a five-year storm, the Board of Public
Works and Safety shall not approve the subdivision until provision has been
made for the improvement of the condition.



      (6)   Open drainage systems shall not be allowed in the front
yards of new development within the jurisdictional areas of the city unless
specifically requested of and granted by the Plan Commission.



      (7)   Swale construction and design shall be performed as
required and specified in the city detailed standards.



(`81 Code, § 151.027)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75; Am. Ord. 99-2324, passed
4-19-99) Penalty, see § 151.99



§ 151.28  STREET NAME SIGNS.



   The Board of Public Works and Safety shall require the installation of
durable street name signs at all intersections, as approved by the City
Engineer or the Traffic Improvement Department, and supplied by the developer.



(`81 Code, § 151.028)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75) Penalty, see § 151.99



§ 151.29  COMPLETION OF IMPROVEMENTS.



   (A)   After the final plat of any subdivided area has been approved
by the Plan Commission, but before it has been recorded, the subdivider shall
post with the Clerk-Treasurer a performance bond, as defined in § 151.002.
The subdivider shall then make and install improvements listed above,
constructed in a manner approved by the Plan Commission and the Board of
Public Works and Safety. All improvements shall be completed within one year
of final plat approval by the Plan Commission.



   (B)   The performance bond shall be conditioned on the payment of
all construction costs incurred in making the improvements by the subdivider,
any expense incurred by the city for engineering and legal fees, and other
expenses in connection with the making of the improvements.



   (C)   In lieu of final completion of the improvements and in lieu of
entering into a contract with the city to insure completion of the
improvements within one year, the improvements may be installed as otherwise
provided by law. In the event of unforeseeable circumstances, an additional
time period for development may be negotiated.



(`81 Code, § 151.029)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75; Am. Ord. 98-2293, passed
2-17-99) Penalty, see § 151.99



§ 151.30  VARIANCES.



   (A)   The Board of Public Works and Safety may grant a variance to
this chapter where, by reason of the unusual shape of a specific piece of
property, or where, by reason of exceptional topographical conditions, the
strict application of these regulations would result in extreme practical
difficulties and undue hardship upon the owner of the property.



      (1)   Such relief may be granted only if it is without
detriment to the public good and does not substantially impair the intent and
purpose of this chapter.



      (2)   In granting such variances or modifications, the Board
of Public Works and Safety may require conditions that will substantially
secure the objectives of the standards or requirements so varied or modified.



      (3)   Financial disadvantage to the property owner is not
proof of hardship within the purpose of this chapter.



   (B)   A comprehensive group housing, commercial, or industrial
development, including the large-scale construction of housing, commercial,
or industrial units together with necessary drives and ways of access, may be
approved by the Board of Public Works and Safety although the design of the
project does not include standard street, lot, and subdivision arrangements,
provided departure from the standards of these regulations can be made
without destroying their intent and is in accordance with the provisions of
the Zoning Code relating to planned development.



   (C)   Where a proposed subdivision would contain no more than five,
but not less than two parcels or plots of land and no new streets, the
procedure of preparing a preliminary plat may be waived by the Board of
Public Works and Safety.



(`81 Code, § 151.030)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75) Penalty, see § 151.99



Cross-reference:



   Zoning regulations as to planned development, see §§ 150.095 through
150.099



ADMINISTRATION



§ 151.35 REVIEW AND APPROVAL OF SUBDIVISION PLAT.



       The procedure for review and approval of a subdivision plat shall
conform to those steps as set forth in the “Developer Handbook” and
approved by the Plan Commission.



(`81 Code, § 151.035)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75; Am. Ord. 96-2230, passed
12-16-96; Am. Ord. 98-2293, passed 2-17-99) Penalty, see § 151.99



Cross-reference:



   Advisory meeting with Plan Commission, see § 151.37



   Preliminary plat, see § 151.38



   Final plat, see § 151.41



§ 151.36  DEVELOPER REVIEW.



       Any development of a commercial or industrial nature, which is
not a subdivision, mobile home park, apartment complex or condominium
development, shall conform to those steps as set forth in the “Developer
Handbook” and approved by the Plan Commission.



(`81 Code, § 151.0355)  (Ord. 98-2293, passed 2-17-99)



§ 151.37  ADVISORY MEETING WITH PLAN COMMISSION.



       (A)   Whenever the owner of any tract or parcel of land in the
jurisdictional area of the city has heretofore made, without recording, a
plat thereof as required by law, or shall hereafter make or intend to make a
subdivision of the same, the subdivider may, before preparing a preliminary
plat, meet and consult informally with the Plan Commission for the purpose of
ascertaining the locations of proposed major streets, parks, playgrounds,
school sites, and other planned projects which may affect the property being
considered for subdivision.



       (B)   At the same meeting, the subdivider should review with
the Plan Commission the minimum standards of subdivision design set forth in
the Developer Handbook. This informal review should prevent unnecessary and
costly revisions in the layout and development of the subdivision.



(`81 Code, § 151.036)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75; Am. Ord. 98-2293, passed
2-17-99) Penalty, see § 151.99



§ 151.38  PRELIMINARY PLAT APPROVAL.



       Any preliminary plat prepared for submission and approval by the
Plan Commission shall conform to the standards required by the Developer
Handbook.



(`81 Code, § 151.037)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75; Am. Ord. 94-2137, passed
4-4-94; Am. Ord. 96-2231, passed 1-6-97; Am. Ord. 98-2293, passed 2-17-99)
Penalty, see § 151.99



§ 151.39  PLAT DRAWINGS.



       The subdivider or developer shall submit the required number of
complete drawings to the Executive Director of the Plan Commission as
required in the Developer Handbook.



(`81 Code, § 151.0375)  (Ord. 96-2230, passed 12-16-96; Am. Ord. 98-2293,
passed 2-17-99)



§ 151.40  CONSTRUCTION PLAN REQUIREMENTS.



       The developer shall submit construction plans that conform to the
required standards as established and set forth in the Developer Handbook.



(`81 Code, § 151.0377)  (Ord. 98-2293, passed 2-17-99)



§ 151.41  FINAL PLAT APPROVAL.



       Any final plat prepared for submission and approval by the Plan
Commission shall conform to the standards required by the Developer Handbook.



(`81 Code, § 151.038)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75; Am. Ord. 98-2293, passed
2-17-99) Penalty, see § 151.99



§ 151.42  VACATION OF PLAT.



       (A)   Power is given to the city to vacate any existing plat
and addition to the city, or part or parts thereof, as the city may deem
advantageous and best for its interests, and the power granted shall be
exercised by the city upon the petition of the owner or all the owners of
lots or lands in the plat or addition.



   (B)   The order vacating the plat or addition shall specify whether
and what public highways, streets, alleys, and public grounds are to be
retained by the city; otherwise the ways, streets, and public grounds shall
upon the vacation revert to the owner or owners of lots or lands abutting the
same in proportion to the respective ownerships of the lots or grounds. In
case of total or partial vacation of the plat or addition, the order
providing therefor shall be, at the cost of the owner or owners, certified to
the office of the County Recorder and be there recorded by the owner or
owners. The County Recorder shall then note the total or partial vacation of
the plat or addition by writing  in plain and legible letters upon the plat
or portion so vacated the word vacated, along with reference to the volume
and page in which the order of vacation is recorded. The owner or owners of
the lots and lands in a plat so vacated may cause the same and the
proportionate part of the abutting highway, streets, alleys, and public
grounds vacated to be replatted and numbered by the City or County Surveyor.
When the replat is acknowledged by the owner or owners and is recorded in the
office of the County Recorder, the property replatted may be conveyed and
assessed by the numbers given in the replat.



(`81 Code, § 151.039)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75) Penalty, see § 151.99



§ 151.43  AMENDMENTS.



       Any provision of this chapter from time to time may be amended,
supplemented, changed, modified, or repealed by the City Council according to
law; however amendments, supplements, changes, modifications, or repealed
provisions shall not become effective unless made after study and report by
the Plan Commission.



(`81 Code, § 151.040)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75) Penalty, see § 151.99



§ 151.44  ENFORCEMENT.



       No plat, plan, or subdivision of land located within the
jurisdiction of this chapter shall be admitted to the records of the county
or be received or recorded by the County Recorder until the plat has received
final approval in writing by the Plan Commission and the Board of Public
Works and Safety.



(`81 Code, § 151.041)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75) Penalty, see § 151.99



Cross-reference:



   Final plat approval, see § 151.41



§ 151.45  REVIEW FEES.



   (A)   Plat review fee.



      (1)   A fee shall be levied for the examination, and approval
or disapproval of every subdivision plat reviewed by the Plan Commission as
follows:



         (a)   $300 plat fee.



         (b)   $50 per lot for first 24 lots.



         (c)   $35 per lot for the next 50 lots.



         (d)   $25 per lot for all lots over 74.



   Should additional costs be incurred by the city for review, the costs
will be paid by the subdivider.



      (2)   A fee shall be levied for the examination and approval
or disapproval of every apartment complex and condominium development plat
reviewed by the Plan Commission as follows:



         (a)   $300 base charge.



           (b)   $20 per dwelling unit for first 24 units.



         (c)   $15 per dwelling unit for next 50 units.



         (d)   $10 per dwelling unit over 74 units.



   Should additional costs be incurred by the city for review, the costs
will be paid by the subdivider.



      (3)   A fee of $500 shall be levied for the examination and
approval or disapproval of every commercial/industrial expansion. Should
additional costs be incurred by the city for review of the plat, the costs
will be paid by the subdivider.



(`81 Code, § 151.042)  (Ord. 98-2293, passed 2-17-99)



§ 151.46  LOCATION IMPROVEMENT PERMIT.



   No improvements shall be made by the developer or his or her agent
until a location improvement permit has been obtained from the office of the
Plan Commission. The cost of the location improvement permit shall be $30
payable to the office of the Plan Commission.



(`81 Code, § 151.043)  (Ord. 98-2293, passed 2-17-99)



§ 151.99  PENALTY.



   Whoever, being the owner or agent of the owner of any land, transfers,
sells, otherwise disposes of, leases, or offers for sale or lease, any lots
in the city, or addition to the city, until the plat has been approved by the
Plan Commission and has been duly acknowledged and recorded as provided in §
151.41 of this chapter, shall forfeit and pay to the city the sum of $50 for
each lot and part of lot sold or otherwise disposed of, leased, or offered
for sale or lease. The city may enjoin the transfer, sale, other disposition,
or lease by action for injunction brought in the appropriate court.



(`81 Code, § 151.099)  (Ord. 1612, passed 10-6-75)
